Expressive variational quantum circuits provide inherent privacy in federated learning

Niraj Kumar niraj.x7.kumar@jpmchase.com Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017    Jamie Heredge Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia    Changhao Li Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017    Shaltiel Eloul Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017    Shree Hari Sureshbabu Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017    Marco Pistoia Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017
Abstract

Federated learning has emerged as a viable distributed solution to train machine learning models without the actual need to share data with the central aggregator. However, standard neural network-based federated learning models have been shown to be susceptible to data leakage from the gradients shared with the server. In this work, we introduce federated learning with variational quantum circuit model built using expressive encoding maps coupled with overparameterized ansätze. We show that expressive maps lead to inherent privacy against gradient inversion attacks, while overparameterization ensures model trainability. Our privacy framework centers on the complexity of solving the system of high-degree multivariate Chebyshev polynomials generated by the gradients of quantum circuit. We present compelling arguments highlighting the inherent difficulty in solving these equations, both in exact and approximate scenarios. Additionally, we delve into machine learning-based attack strategies and establish a direct connection between overparameterization in the original federated learning model and underparameterization in the attack model. Furthermore, we provide numerical scaling arguments showcasing that underparameterization of the expressive map in the attack model leads to the loss landscape being swamped with exponentially many spurious local minima points, thus making it extremely hard to realize a successful attack. This provides a strong claim, for the first time, that the nature of quantum machine learning models inherently helps prevent data leakage in federated learning.

I Introduction

The recent advances in the field of machine learning, particularly deep learning, have found tremendous success across a wide variety of areas including computer vision, natural language processing, generative modeling, and time-series forecasting among many others [1, 2, 3]. With the recent explosion of the abundance of data and powerful computing models, every passing year sees increasing success and impact across the above-mentioned fields using machine learning.

In parallel, quantum computing, and quantum machine learning [4] in particular, has emerged as an interdisciplinary field with the potential to significantly impact a wide range of fields. Some initial results, along with theoretical guarantees, have showcased its potential computational advantage over classical machine learning tasks such as in classification, and distribution learning among others [5, 6, 7]. Some notable examples of quantum machine learning algorithms include the Harrow-Hassidim-Lloyd (HHL) for solving linear systems of equations, quantum principal component analysis, quantum generative models, quantum support vector machines, quantum branch and bound, and quantum Monte-Carlo estimation, among others [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13].

However, numerous machine learning algorithms require substantial amounts of data to construct robust, high-performing models. In practice, data is often fragmented across various organizations or devices due to factors like privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR [14]) or the logistical challenges of centralizing data collection. For instance, medical data from different hospitals is typically sensitive and confined to individual facilities. This limited and potentially biased data pool makes it challenging to develop accurate models for specific tasks, such as disease pattern identification [15].

The imperative need for data privacy, coupled with concerns related to storage and computational resources, has seen growing interest in the field of distributed learning. One prominent solution is Federated Learning (FL), which addresses this challenge by forming a loose federation of participating devices, referred to as clients, all coordinated by a central server [16, 17]. Importantly, each client has a local training dataset which is never uploaded to the central server. Instead, each client computes an update, typically the model cost function gradient, and transmits only this gradient to the global model maintained by the central server, which we call the FL model. The role of the server is to act as a central aggregator of the gradients in order to globally update the FL model. FL approaches have been adopted by various service providers and play a pivotal role in privacy-conscious applications where training data is distributed across multiple clients. Its potential applications are diverse, including sentiment analysis among mobile phone users, enhancing autonomous driving systems, predicting health events such as heart rate risks from wearable devices, improving image detection through data contributed by multiple phone and tablet users, and many more [18, 15, 19, 20, 21].

Previous studies have shown that sharing gradient information with the central honest-but-curious server can potentially expose clients to sensitive data leakage scenarios [22, 23]. An honest-but-curious attack model is where the server still performs the gradient aggregation, but could also perform a local gradient inversion-based attack to learn the client’s data. This compromise in privacy prevents the FL framework from becoming fully trustworthy for distributed machine learning models. While some studies have indicated that it is possible to partially protect against gradient inversion attacks by employing techniques like gradient masking and introducing random noise [16, 24], or by maximizing the mixing of gradients [25], these approaches are not completely robust. They may still leak some data information, or add substantial additional computational overhead, while also in certain cases, reducing the predictive capability of the model.

In this work, we introduce the quantum version of the federated learning framework where we replace the classical neural network-based FL models with variational quantum circuits (VQC) [26]. We specifically consider VQCs which have a high expressive capability, meaning, they comprise a significant number of non-degenerate Fourier frequencies when representing the model output in the Fourier basis as was originally introduced in [27, 28] and later explored in [29, 30, 31]. Our particular emphasis lies in constructing a product encoding map that leads to an exponential increase in the number of frequencies per input dimension when representing the model output and its cost function gradients as functions of the input data. Additionally, the trainable ansatz in these VQCs incorporates a sufficiently large number of trainable parameters within the variational ansatz, rendering them overparameterized [32, 33]. In particular, we consider the overparameterized hardware efficient ansatz (HEA) where the number of trainable parameters scales exponentially with the number of qubits Nqsubscript𝑁𝑞N_{q} [33]. Our choice of expressive encoding map coupled with overparameterized ansatz ensures that the FL model would be able to easily fit a large variety of functions during training and does not suffer the problem of spurious local minima, as all the local minima points exponentially concentrate around the global minimum [28, 33].

Our key contribution is to establish that the gradients generated by the considered VQCs result in a system of multivariate Chebyshev polynomial equations with an exponential degree (in the number of qubits) when expressed as a function of input i.e. in the input space111The gradients can alternatively be written as a system of equations generated by the model output which is linear in the feature space i.e., when represented as the function of an input encoded quantum state. We also study the difficulty of learning the input by solving this system of equations in Sec. VI.3.7.. Here, the number of equations is determined by the number of gradients shared, i.e., the number of trainable parameters in the model. Thus, in order to invert the gradients and subsequently learn the data, the task amounts to simultaneously solving these systems of high-degree multivariate equations. We initially tackle the inherent challenge associated with analytically solving these equations, both in exact and approximate scenarios. In the case of exact solutions, we employ techniques from computational algebraic geometry, such as Buchberger’s algorithm [34], to provide an upper bound on exact equation solving. For approximate solutions, we utilize the Nyquist-Shannon theorem [35] to show formulating an approximate system of equations is hard. Both these approaches require time and memory resources scaling exponentially in the number of qubits, thus providing significant privacy in our VQC based FL model.

We also investigate the challenge of retrieving client data via the machine learning technique, the most common gradient inversion attack setting in the standard neural network-based FL models [22, 23, 25]. Here, the server generates dummy gradients in their attack model and trains the model with a suitable loss function to match the client’s gradients in order to learn the input. Our observation, backed by numerical results, reveals that the attack model in this context faces a significant challenge. It is severely underparameterized, yet highly expressive, meaning it incorporates an exponential number of Fourier frequencies. This results in the loss landscape being riddled with exponentially many spurious local minima which are well separated thus resulting in the untrainability of the attack model, preventing it from easily recovering the original input. This provides compelling evidence that the expressive encoding maps associated with quantum machine learning models are well placed to help prevent data leakage attacks in FL models.

The next sections are structured in the following manner. Sec. II discusses related work in the FL and quantum FL literature. We introduce the notion of FL in Sec. III along with the system of equations generated in the fully connected neural network model which is linear in the input space. Sec. IV introduces quantum federated learning. In Sec. V we discuss the expressivity of VQCs in general and our specific FL model VQC. Sec. VI conceptually highlights the privacy of our quantum FL model which is then further supported by numerical results in Sec. VII. We finally conclude our results in Sec. VIII.

II Related Work

Privacy in federated learning models has been challenged by the wider community [36]. Led by [37] and followed by many others [22, 38, 39, 40], it was shown that it is possible to extract input data from model gradients. Typical works on inversion attacks in federated learning of classical neural networks share the same principal of guessing the input that generate similar gradients shared by a client. Hence, the attacker goal is to optimize a proxy model to the gradients shared. The results of this attack have shown that it is possible, with relatively ease, to extract data at a pixel-level for full batch images with clarity [39, 41, 38]. Bayes frameworks and generative model priors to various input data distributions have been shown to improve inversion success rates, by providing better prior distributions to circumvent several defenses and allow better convergences of various optimizers [42]. For example, [43] show how to train a generative model prior, resulting in a high success rate of attacks over several image databases. Overall, mechanisms to enhance privacy have been proposed, but mainly relying on empirical approaches of noise addition and information compression with a range of effectiveness [36, 44, 23, 45]. Such defenses includes dropout nodes, gradient pruning, noise injection to the gradients [37, 46, 45] blending methods of training images applied online by the client nodes [47], and also mixing gradients strategies [25]. Here, instead of standard machine learning models, we introduce trainable quantum circuits and quantum encoding as a potential resistance strategy for defense. Recent works have shown the applicability of quantum federated learning setup [48] and potential added value for privacy [49, 50] in using quantum machine learning, however, such intuition was not analyzed nor quantified thoroughly. Here we look into the leakage of data in quantum federated learning using variational quantum circuits, and analyze privacy against a multitude of attack strategies on the client’s gradients generated using variational quantum circuits architectures.

III.2 Task of clients and server

In the standard federated learning setup, at the t𝑡t-th iteration, the clients each receive the parameter values 𝜽t∈ℝdsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from the server and their task is to compute the gradients with respect to 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t} and send it back to the server. Here the superscript denotes the iteration step. Upon performing a single batch training, they compute the d𝑑d gradient updates and share it with the server,

Ci,j=∂Costi​(𝜽t)∂θjt,∀i∈[l],j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscriptCost𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑗formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑙𝑗delimited-[]𝑑C_{i,j}=\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t})}{\partial\theta^{t}_{j}},\hskip 5.69054pt\forall i\in[l],j\in[d] (3)

θjt+1→θjt−η​∑i=1lpi​Ci,j,∀j∈[d]formulae-sequence→superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑙subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑\displaystyle\theta_{j}^{t+1}\rightarrow\theta_{j}^{t}-\eta\sum_{i=1}^{l}p_{i}C_{i,j},\hskip 5.69054pt\forall j\in[d] (4)

The parameters 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1} are then communicated back to the clients and the protocol repeats until a desired stopping criteria is reached.

III.3 Data leakage from gradients in the standard Neural Network based FL

Here we analyze one major data leakage issue with the standard classical federated learning approach, namely its susceptibility to the gradient inversion attack by the honest-but-curious server in successfully recovering the data from the received gradients [25, 22]. Let us look at the vulnerability of recovering averaged data information where the model considered for training is the fully connected neural network layer as highlighted in Fig. 2. To simplify the analysis, we consider a dense linear layer containing 𝐱=x1​⋯​xn𝐱subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛\mathbf{x}=x_{1}\cdots x_{n} as input and y∈𝒞𝑦𝒞y\in\mathcal{C} as output333We represent the y𝑦y as y1​⋯​y|𝒞|subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦𝒞y_{1}\cdots y_{|\mathcal{C}|} such that y=ci𝑦subscript𝑐𝑖y=c_{i} implies yi=1subscript𝑦𝑖1y_{i}=1 and rest being zero. This gives us |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| number of finite output classes. As an example, for |𝒞|=3𝒞3|\mathcal{C}|=3, the set 𝒞={a1:100,a2:010,a3:001}𝒞conditional-setsubscript𝑎1:100subscript𝑎2010subscript𝑎3:001\mathcal{C}=\{a_{1}:100,a_{2}:010,a_{3}:001\}., where the dense layer is oj=∑i=1nwi​j​xi+bjsubscript𝑜𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑏𝑗o_{j}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{ij}x_{i}+b_{j}. Given a known y𝑦y, 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} can be inverted successfully, and any additional hidden layers can be inverted by back-propagation.

Consider a typical classification architecture which uses softmax activation function, pk=eok∑jeojsubscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑒subscript𝑜𝑘subscript𝑗superscript𝑒subscript𝑜𝑗p_{k}=\frac{e^{o_{k}}}{\sum_{j}e^{o_{j}}} to create the model label y​(𝐰,𝐛)=carg max​(pk)𝑦𝐰𝐛subscript𝑐arg maxsubscript𝑝𝑘y(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{b})=c_{\text{arg max}(p_{k})}, followed by the cross entropy to obtain the cost value,

and,

∂Cost∂bj=k=pj−yjCostsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}}{\partial b_{j=k}}=p_{j}-y_{j} (8)

From this, it can be seen that the number of gradient equations shared with the server would be n​|𝒞|+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞𝒞n|\mathcal{C}|+|\mathcal{C}| while the number of unknowns is n+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞n+|\mathcal{C}|. In the above setting we saw that for batch size B=1𝐵1B=1, the number of unknowns is less than the number of equations and thus the unknowns can be trivially recovered from the system of equations generated by the dense linear layer of the neural network.

Let us now see what happens if we consider the mini-batch size training with B>1𝐵1B>1. Here, the client trains with the inputs Samp:=[(𝐱κ,yκ)κ∈Samp]assignSampdelimited-[]subscriptsubscript𝐱𝜅subscript𝑦𝜅𝜅Samp\text{Samp}:=[(\mathbf{x}_{\kappa},y_{\kappa})_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}] and only shares the averaged gradient information (over the data points with B=|Samp|𝐵SampB=|\text{Samp}|) with the server,

∂Cost∂wi,j=k=1B​∑κ∈Samp(pκ​j−yκ​j)​xκ​iCostsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑘1𝐵subscript𝜅Sampsubscript𝑝𝜅𝑗subscript𝑦𝜅𝑗subscript𝑥𝜅𝑖\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}}{\partial w_{i,j=k}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}(p_{\kappa j}-y_{\kappa j})x_{\kappa i} (10)

and,

∂Cost∂bj=k=1B​∑κ∈Samppκ​j−yκ​jCostsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑘1𝐵subscript𝜅Sampsubscript𝑝𝜅𝑗subscript𝑦𝜅𝑗\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}}{\partial b_{j=k}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}p_{\kappa j}-y_{\kappa j} (11)

In this scenario, the number of equations shared is still n​|𝒞|+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞𝒞n|\mathcal{C}|+|\mathcal{C}|, whereas the number of unknowns is now B​(n+|𝒞|)𝐵𝑛𝒞B(n+|\mathcal{C}|). Thus the number of unknowns can now exceed the number of equations, resulting in no unique solution for the server when attempting to solve the system of equations. Even in the case that a unique solution exists, numerical optimization can be challenging. However, in the scenario where softmax follows the cross entropy, the authors in [25] show that one can obtain an accurate direct solution in many cases even when B≫1much-greater-than𝐵1B\gg 1, due to the demixing property across the batch making it easy for the server to retrieve the data points in Samp.

Certain strategies have been employed in the classical world to prevent the data leakage from the gradients, for example using convolution neural network layers instead of the fully connected layers, or using differential privacy (adding random noise perturbations to the gradients before communicating them with the server), or using classical homomorphic encryption. However, these results either do not guarantee complete data leakage prevention, or prevent data leakage at the cost of reduced model performance or increased communication resource overhead.

This begs a natural question,

Do quantum machine learning models, when employed in the standard federated learning setup, naturally offer data leakage prevention which the existing neural-network based classical models fail to do?

IV Quantum Federated Learning

Quantum federated learning (QFL) has the same setup as the classical federated learning except that the model to be trained is a variational quantum circuit (VQC) instead of a classical neural network. Below we briefly describe the key components of a variational quantum circuit [26] necessary for our construction. Subsequently, we explicitly describe the setup of QFL.

IV.1 Variational quantum circuit

VQCs are hybrid quantum-classical algorithms where a quantum circuit with trainable parameters is trained iteratively with respect to a classical optimizer as highlighted in Fig. 3. The key components of the VQC are: data encoding map, trainable ansatz, cost function, and gradient estimation.

IV.1.1 Unitary to load the classical data

Loading the classical input data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} into the quantum circuit is the key to the performance of the VQC. This mapping is defined as,

𝐱→U​(γ​𝐱)→𝐱𝑈𝛾𝐱\mathbf{x}\rightarrow U(\mathbf{\gamma x}) (12)

where 𝐱∈[0,1]n𝐱superscript01𝑛\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n}, γ𝛾\gamma is the appropriate scaling factor when mapping the classical input into the quantum circuit, and the map U(.)U(.) is the unitary map defined on m𝑚m qubits, where m𝑚m can in general be different to n𝑛n. For example, in the case of amplitude encoding, the encoding map is,

U​(𝐱)=1‖𝐱‖2​∑i=1nxi​|i⟩𝑈𝐱1subscriptnorm𝐱2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖ket𝑖U(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{\|\mathbf{x}\|_{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\ket{i} (13)

where m=𝒪​(log⁡n)𝑚𝒪𝑛m=\mathcal{O}(\log n) and the state can be prepared in time 𝒪​(poly​log⁡n)𝒪poly𝑛\mathcal{O}(\emph{poly}\log n) time using appropriate quantum random access memory model [51, 10].

The choice of the data-uploading unitary is the key to the performance of the VQC as it inherently decides the types of functions (or input/output relationships) that can be learned. In other words, following the results of [28], the output of a variational quantum circuit can be written in the Fourier function basis where the frequency spectrum is solely determined by the expressive capability of the quantum encoding map. This implies that the VQC model’s capability to learn any unknown function increases as one increases the expressivity of the encoding map. In the following sections, we also show that expressivity is directly tied to data privacy in the quantum federated learning setup where the intuition is that a highly expressible encoding map would create a very complex polynomial system of equations for the server to solve which directly ties to the hardness in retrieving the client’s data.

Consequently, in this work, we will consider highly expressive the product feature maps of the type which gives rise to an exponential encoding scheme meaning exponential (in the number of qubits) Fourier spectra as we showcase in Sec. V. Specifically the map we consider is the product map, which we refer to as the Fourier tower map, considered in [29].

The Fourier tower map takes the input 𝐱∈[0,1]n𝐱superscript01𝑛\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n} and realizes the following unitary map on Nq=n​msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑛𝑚N_{q}=nm qubits,

U​(𝐱)=⨂j=1n⨂k=1mRσ​(γ​βj​k​γ​xj)𝑈𝐱superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑘1𝑚subscript𝑅𝜎𝛾subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘𝛾subscript𝑥𝑗U(\mathbf{x})=\bigotimes_{j=1}^{n}\bigotimes_{k=1}^{m}R_{\sigma}\left(\gamma\beta_{jk}\gamma x_{j}\right) (14)

where the unitary acts on the input state |0⟩⊗Nqsuperscriptket0tensor-productabsentsubscript𝑁𝑞\ket{0}^{\otimes N_{q}} and Rσ​(βj​k​xj)=exp⁡(−i​γ​βj​k​xj​σ/2)subscript𝑅𝜎subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗𝑖𝛾subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗𝜎2R_{\sigma}\left(\beta_{jk}x_{j}\right)=\exp\left(-i\gamma\beta_{jk}x_{j}\sigma/2\right) is the Pauli rotation operation for the Pauli matrices σ=X,Y,𝜎𝑋𝑌\sigma=X,Y, or Z𝑍Z. Here m𝑚m is the number of encoding gates chosen per variable of the input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, γ=2​π𝛾2𝜋\gamma=2\pi is the scaling factor chosen444The scaling factor of γ=2​π𝛾2𝜋\gamma=2\pi reflects the fact that the input x𝑥x lies within a unit hypercube. Thus multiplying the input by 2​π2𝜋2\pi allows the gate Rσ​(βj​k​xj)subscript𝑅𝜎subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗R_{\sigma}(\beta_{jk}x_{j}) to explore all possible angles from [0,2​π]02𝜋[0,2\pi] for all βj​k≥1subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘1\beta_{jk}\geq 1., and βj​ksubscript𝛽𝑗𝑘\beta_{jk} is the term added to increase the Fourier spectra of the model as we show in Sec. V.2.1. In [29], the authors choose σ=Z𝜎𝑍\sigma=Z and showcase that if βj​k=3k−1subscript𝛽𝑗𝑘superscript3𝑘1\beta_{jk}=3^{k-1}, then the model output can be written in a dense encoding fashion with a total of 3msuperscript3𝑚3^{m} frequencies in the range of [−(3m−1)/2,(3m−1)/2]superscript3𝑚12superscript3𝑚12[-(3^{m}-1)/2,(3^{m}-1)/2]. Here dense encoding implies that the difference between the k+1𝑘1k+1-th and k𝑘k-th frequency is always 1 indicating that this gives rise to a compact encoding. The degree of the Fourier expansion corresponding to the model output dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F} is the largest Fourier frequency component. Thus if we want to create a model output with a desired degree dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F}, then in the case of above encoding, m=log3⁡(2​dF+1)𝑚subscript32subscript𝑑𝐹1m=\log_{3}(2d_{F}+1). In the context of quantum federated learning, we are interested in the having a compact encoding corresponding to cost function gradient representation in terms of the Fourier series. As we show in Sec. V.2.1, the corresponding encoding map which gives us the dense encoding is,

U​(𝐱)=⨂j=1n⨂k=1mRX​(5k−1​xj)𝑈𝐱superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑘1𝑚subscript𝑅𝑋superscript5𝑘1subscript𝑥𝑗U(\mathbf{x})=\bigotimes_{j=1}^{n}\bigotimes_{k=1}^{m}R_{X}\left(5^{k-1}x_{j}\right) (15)

We note that expanding the model’s output in terms of Fourier spectra is not the only method to quantify expressivity. Other works have instead considered data uploading maps which gives rise to Chebyshev polynomials of first and second degree [52, 53] as we also leverage in showcasing the privacy of quantum federated learning models in Sec. VI.2. As Chebyshev polynomials are universal set of overcomplete basis functions, the degree of polynomials generated by the data uploading maps then relates to the expressivity of such quantum models [54].

IV.1.2 Trainable ansätze

Another important aspect of a VQC is its trainable variational ansatz. Generically speaking the form of the ansatz dictates how the parameters 𝜽∈[0,2​π]d𝜽superscript02𝜋𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in[0,2\pi]^{d} can be trained in order to minimize the desired cost function. Without the loss of generality, the ansatz can be expressed as,

W​(𝜽)=Wd​(θd)​Wd−1​(θd−1)​⋯​W1​(θ1)𝑊𝜽subscript𝑊𝑑subscript𝜃𝑑subscript𝑊𝑑1subscript𝜃𝑑1⋯subscript𝑊1subscript𝜃1W(\boldsymbol{\theta})=W_{d}(\theta_{d})W_{d-1}(\theta_{d-1})\cdots W_{1}(\theta_{1}) (16)

where the unitary has the form Wl​(θl)=exp⁡(−i​θl​Hl)subscript𝑊𝑙subscript𝜃𝑙𝑖subscript𝜃𝑙subscript𝐻𝑙W_{l}(\theta_{l})=\exp(-i\theta_{l}H_{l}), where Hlsubscript𝐻𝑙H_{l} is the Hermitian operator which generates the quantum gate and θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} is the trainable parameter.

The specific structure of an ansatz will generally depend on the task at hand, as in many cases one can use information about the problem to tailor an ansatz. These are the so-called problem-inspired ansätze with a few examples being the unitary coupled clustered ansatz, quantum alternating operator ansatz, variable structure ansatz [55, 56, 57, 58]. However, some ansatz architectures are generic and problem-agnostic, meaning that they can be used even when no relevant information is readily available, for example the hardware efficient ansatz (HEA) [59].

In this work we restrict our numerical investigation to HEA although any other choice of the ansatz would be equally valid for quantum federated learning. The structure of HEA we consider, consists of concatenated layers of single qubit rotations of RY−RZsubscript𝑅𝑌subscript𝑅𝑍R_{Y}-R_{Z} sequenced in each qubit in Nqsubscript𝑁𝑞N_{q}, which are parameterized by independent angles θ𝜃\theta which can produce arbitrary single qubit rotations in S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2). This is followed by a non-parameterized entangling layer CNOT. The CNOT operation applies between the nearest neighbour qubits. The combination of single qubit layers and CNOT form one block of the ansatz. We apply L𝐿L such blocks to form the complete ansatz structure such that the total number of trainable parameters in the ansatz is d=2​L​Nq𝑑2𝐿subscript𝑁𝑞d=2LN_{q}. The ansatz is then written as,

W​(𝜽)=⨂i=1L[⨂j=1NqRY,j​(θj,2​i−1)​RZ,j​(θj,2​i)​C​N​O​T​(j,j+1)]𝑊𝜽superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑖1𝐿delimited-[]superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑞subscript𝑅𝑌𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗2𝑖1subscript𝑅𝑍𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗2𝑖𝐶𝑁𝑂𝑇𝑗𝑗1\small W(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{L}\left[\bigotimes_{j=1}^{N_{q}}R_{Y,j}(\theta_{j,2i-1})R_{Z,j}(\theta_{j,2i})CNOT(j,j+1)\right] (17)

Combining the data uploading unitary, and the trainable ansatz, the combined unitary can be expressed as,

U​(𝐱;𝜽)=W​(𝜽)​U​(γ​𝐱)𝑈𝐱𝜽𝑊𝜽𝑈𝛾𝐱U(\mathbf{x};\boldsymbol{\theta})=W(\boldsymbol{\theta})U(\gamma\mathbf{x}) (18)

IV.1.3 Cost function

Similar to classical machine learning, for the VQC, one defines the cost function Cost which, in the case of supervised learning with training dataset 𝐗,Y={𝐱i,yi},i∈Nformulae-sequence𝐗𝑌subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖𝑁\mathbf{X},Y=\{\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}\},i\in N where 𝐱i∈[0,1]]n,yi∈𝒞\mathbf{x}_{i}\in[0,1]]^{n},y_{i}\in\mathcal{C} (see Sec. III.1), acts as proxy for the quality of the solution y​(𝐱i,𝜽)𝑦subscript𝐱𝑖𝜽y(\mathbf{x}_{i},\boldsymbol{\theta}) generated by the model in contrast to the true solution yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}. In general, the cost function corresponding to the training dataset can be expressed as,

Cost​(𝜽,𝐗,Y)={fi​(yi,y​(𝐱i,𝜽))}i∈SampCost𝜽𝐗𝑌subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑦subscript𝐱𝑖𝜽𝑖Samp\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{X},Y)=\{f_{i}(y_{i},y(\mathbf{x}_{i},\boldsymbol{\theta}))\}_{i\in\text{Samp}} (19)

where fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is some chosen function (for example cross-entropy loss function, mean squared loss function etc.), and Samp⊆NSamp𝑁\text{Samp}\subseteq N. Subsequently, the set of d𝑑d parameters 𝜽∈[0,2​π]d𝜽superscript02𝜋𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in[0,2\pi]^{d} are optimized to train the model and thus solve the optimization task,

𝜽∗=arg min𝜽​Cost​(𝜽)superscript𝜽subscriptarg min𝜽Cost𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\text{arg min}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) (20)

In this work, we consider the mean squared error loss as the cost function for train the model,

Cost​(𝜽,y​(𝐱i,𝜽),yi)=(yi−y​(𝐱i,𝜽))2Cost𝜽𝑦subscript𝐱𝑖𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑦subscript𝐱𝑖𝜽2\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},y(\mathbf{x}_{i},\boldsymbol{\theta}),y_{i})=\left(y_{i}-y(\mathbf{x}_{i},\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{2} (21)

For simplicity, let us denote the output of the VQC model y​(𝜽,𝐱i)𝑦𝜽subscript𝐱𝑖y(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}_{i}) by yi​(𝜽)subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}). This can be expressed as,

yi​(𝜽)=Tr​[𝐎​W​(𝜽)​U​(γ​𝐱𝐢)​ρi​n​i​t​U†​(γ​𝐱i)​W†​(𝜽)]subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽Trdelimited-[]𝐎𝑊𝜽𝑈𝛾subscript𝐱𝐢subscript𝜌𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡superscript𝑈†𝛾subscript𝐱𝑖superscript𝑊†𝜽y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\text{Tr}[\mathbf{O}W(\boldsymbol{\theta})U(\mathbf{\gamma x_{i}})\rho_{init}U^{\dagger}(\gamma\mathbf{x}_{i})W^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta})] (22)

where ρi​n​i​tsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡\rho_{init} is the initial quantum state which is typically |0⊗Nq⟩​⟨0⊗Nq|ketsuperscript0tensor-productabsentsubscript𝑁𝑞brasuperscript0tensor-productabsentsubscript𝑁𝑞|0^{\otimes N_{q}}\rangle\langle 0^{\otimes N_{q}}|, and 𝐎=∑i∈|𝒞|ci​Oi𝐎subscript𝑖𝒞subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑂𝑖\mathbf{O}=\sum_{i\in|\mathcal{C}|}c_{i}O_{i} is the measurement operator with ∑iOi=𝕀subscript𝑖subscript𝑂𝑖𝕀\sum_{i}O_{i}=\mathbb{I}, where Oisubscript𝑂𝑖O_{i} corresponds to the measurement outcome corresponding to the output class ci∈𝒞subscript𝑐𝑖𝒞c_{i}\in\mathcal{C}.

The property of VQC is that they use a quantum computer to estimate the cost value (or its gradient), while leveraging the power of classical optimizers to train the parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. Some of the desirable criteria for the cost function to meet are, it must be ‘faithful’, meaning the minimum of Cost​(𝜽)Cost𝜽\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) must correspond to the solution of the problem [60]. And secondly, it must be efficient to estimate Cost​(𝜽)Cost𝜽\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) by doing quantum measurement and potential classical post processing. Also the cost must be operationally meaningful to guide us through the optimization and it also must be trainable meaning one should be able to optimize over the set of parameters.

IV.1.4 Gradient estimation with parameter shift rule

Unlike the classical neural network, where the gradients of the cost function are estimated via back propagation, the VQC does not directly offer this possibility. This is primarily because back-propagation would destroy the quantum superposition of the state and thus the data would be irretrievably lost. One could instead perform a finite-difference calculation to estimate the gradients, but this can be too error prone to compute when using hardware, due to inherent gate noise in the quantum system. To resolve this, the authors [61, 62] proposed an analytic version of computing quantum circuit gradients using what is referred as the parameter shift rule.

A common approach to optimize the cost function Cost​(𝜽)Cost𝜽\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is via its gradient, i.e., the change of the function with respect to a variation of its parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} by a common update rule defined by,

𝜽(t+1)=𝜽(t)−η​∇Cost​(𝜽(t))superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡𝜂bold-∇Costsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\eta\boldsymbol{\nabla}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) (23)

where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate.

So our objective is to compute ∇Cost​(𝜽)bold-∇Cost𝜽\boldsymbol{\nabla}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) where the gradient of the cost function can be written as,

∇Cost​(𝜽,𝐗,Y)={∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θ1,⋯,∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θd}∇Cost𝜽𝐗𝑌Cost𝜽subscript𝜃1⋯Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑑\nabla\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{X},Y)=\Big{\{}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{1}},\cdots,\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{d}}\Big{\}} (24)

with the gradients with respect to the individual parameters, θjsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j} being expressed as,

∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj={fi​(yi,∂yi​(𝜽)∂θj)}i∈SampCost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗𝑖Samp\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}=\Big{\{}f_{i}\left(y_{i},\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}\right)\Big{\}}_{i\in\text{Samp}} (25)

As highlighted above, finite difference to compute the gradient would incur additional errors apart from the statistical error (due to the gate noise). We therefore show how to compute the gradient analytically with the macroscopic shifting of the parameters and subsequent computation of the expectations.

In order to compute the gradient with respect the cost function, we need to compute the gradient of the model output i.e. ∂yi​(𝜽)/∂θjsubscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\partial\theta_{j}. For this, let us express the ansatz W​(𝜽)=U​W​(θi)​V𝑊𝜽𝑈𝑊subscript𝜃𝑖𝑉W(\boldsymbol{\theta})=UW(\theta_{i})V, were U,V𝑈𝑉U,V are unitary maps containing other sets of parameters and W​(θj)=exp⁡(−i​θj​Hj)𝑊subscript𝜃𝑗𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝐻𝑗W(\theta_{j})=\exp(-i\theta_{j}H_{j}) is parameterized by θjsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j} with Hjsubscript𝐻𝑗H_{j} being the generator for W𝑊W. If Hjsubscript𝐻𝑗H_{j} has a spectrum of two eigenvalues (which is usually assumed to be the case) labelled by (λ0,λ1)subscript𝜆0subscript𝜆1(\lambda_{0},\lambda_{1}), the gradient can be calculated by measuring the observable at two shifted parameter values as follows,

∂yi​(𝜽)∂θj=r​(yi​(𝜽+)−yi​(𝜽−))subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗𝑟subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}=r(y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})) (26)

where r=λ1−λ02𝑟subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆02r=\frac{\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{0}}{2} and 𝜽±=𝜽±π4​r​𝐞jsuperscript𝜽plus-or-minusplus-or-minus𝜽𝜋4𝑟subscript𝐞𝑗\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\pm}=\boldsymbol{\theta}\pm\frac{\pi}{4r}\mathbf{e}_{j}, where 𝐞jsubscript𝐞𝑗\mathbf{e}_{j} is a vector with all elements equal to 0 except a single 1 located only at the index j𝑗j. Recent results have also extended this rule to the case where the generator Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i} does not satisfy the eigenspectrum condition [63] but for this work, we consider the case where the generator of the ansatz unitary has a two eigenvalue spectrum with r=1/2𝑟12r=1/2, as is the case for most Pauli based and control rotation based generators. Thus the model output gradient takes the form,

∂yi​(𝜽)∂θj=12​(yi​(𝜽+)−yi​(𝜽−))subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗12subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}=\frac{1}{2}(y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})) (27)

In the context of the cost function being mean square error loss function as in Eq. 21, we can see that the gradient with respect to θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} (when cost is defined for single training sample (𝐱i,yi)subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})) can be expressed as,

∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj=−2​(yi−yi​(𝜽))​∂yi​(𝜽)∂θj=−(yi−yi​(𝜽))​(yi​(𝜽+)−yi​(𝜽−))Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗2subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽\begin{split}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}&=-2\left(y_{i}-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}\\ &=-\left(y_{i}-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)(y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-}))\end{split} (28)

The above cost gradient estimation is with respect to training the model with a single sample at a time i.e. batch training with batch size B=1𝐵1B=1. If on the other hand, the cost function is estimated for Samp:=(𝐗,Y)=[(𝐱i,yi)i∈Samp]assignSamp𝐗𝑌delimited-[]subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖Samp\text{Samp}:=(\mathbf{X},Y)=[(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})_{i\in\text{Samp}}], with batch size B=|Samp|𝐵SampB=|\text{Samp}|, then the gradient is expressed as,

∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj=−2B​∑i∈Samp(yi−yi​(𝜽))​∂yi​(𝜽)∂θj=−1B​∑i∈Samp(yi−yi​(𝜽))​(yi​(𝜽+)−yi​(𝜽−))Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗2𝐵subscript𝑖Sampsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗1𝐵subscript𝑖Sampsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽subscript𝑦𝑖superscript𝜽\begin{split}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}&=-\frac{2}{B}\sum_{i\in\text{Samp}}\left(y_{i}-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}\\ &=-\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i\in\text{Samp}}\left(y_{i}-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)\left(y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})\right)\end{split} (29)

IV.2 Federated learning with VQC

We briefly revisit the federated learning setup defined in Sec. III in the context of VQC. The setup consists of l𝑙l clients with each client i∈[l]𝑖delimited-[]𝑙i\in[l] having Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} samples of the form,

𝐗(i),Y(i):{(𝐱j(i),yj(i))}j=1Ni,i∈[l]:superscript𝐗𝑖superscript𝑌𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑙\mathbf{X}^{(i)},Y^{(i)}:\{(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{j},y^{(i)}_{j})\}_{j=1}^{N_{i}},\hskip 5.69054pti\in[l]

such that the total number of samples across all the clients is N=∑i∈[l]Ni𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑙subscript𝑁𝑖N=\sum_{i\in[l]}N_{i}. The aim is to learn the underlying relationship between the example vectors and their labels by training the VQC model under the constraint that the client data is processed and stored locally, with only the intermediate updates being communicated periodically with a central server. In particular, the goal is to minimize the mean squared error loss function as in Eq. 21 with the gradient-based method.

In the setup, at the t𝑡t-th iteration, the clients each receive the parameter values 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t} from the server and their task is to compute the gradients with respect to 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t} and send it back to the server. In the case of batch training with batch size B=1𝐵1B=1, the clients compute their gradients according to Eq. 28, or alternatively with Eq. 29 when B>1𝐵1B>1. Upon performing a single batch training, each client i𝑖i shares the d𝑑d gradient updates with the server referred as,

Ci,j=∂Costi​(𝜽t)∂θjt,∀i∈[l],j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗subscriptCost𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑗formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑙𝑗delimited-[]𝑑C_{i,j}=\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t})}{\partial\theta^{t}_{j}},\hskip 5.69054pt\forall i\in[l],j\in[d] (30)

The server’s task is then to perform the gradient aggregation to update the next set of parameters 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1} using the rule,

θjt+1→θjt−α​∑i=1lpi​Ci,j,∀j∈[d]formulae-sequence→superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑙subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑\displaystyle\theta_{j}^{t+1}\rightarrow\theta_{j}^{t}-\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{l}p_{i}C_{i,j},\hskip 5.69054pt\forall j\in[d] (31)

where pi=NiNsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖𝑁p_{i}=\frac{N_{i}}{N}, and α𝛼\alpha is some suitably chosen learning rate hyperparameter by the server.

Thus it becomes clear that in a single batch training, each client shares d𝑑d gradient updates (and hence d𝑑d equations) with the server, while the number of unknowns from the server’s perspective is B​(n+|𝒞|)𝐵𝑛𝒞B(n+|\mathcal{C}|) for each client (given that the inputs 𝐱i∈ℝnsubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and the target label can be in any of one of the |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| classes).

Next, we consider the question of privacy of client’s data from the honest-but-curious server’s perspective where the task of the server effectively boils down to extracting the unknowns from the shared gradient information. Here we consider the worst-case data-leakage scenario for the clients where we quantify the hardness of learning even a single input-output data from the clients i.e. batch size B=1𝐵1B=1. In order to prove privacy, we connect privacy with expressivity of VQCs. In the next section, we quantify the expressivity of the quantum model in terms of the frequency spectra generated by the VQC as shown by [28].

V Expressivity of VQC

Here we first showcase that a general VQC model output and the cost function gradient can be expressed as the sum of Fourier basis functions. Subsequently, we quantify the expressivity of our VQC model (as defined in Sec. IV.1) in terms of non-degenerate Fourier spectra.

V.1 General VQC Fourier expansion

V.1.1 Univariate input analysis

Let us start our analysis with the univariate input x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] and characterize the function y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}). The univariate function that the quantum circuit outputs with respect to an observable 𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O} is then,

y(𝜽)=Tr[𝐎W(𝜽)U(γx)|0⊗Nq⟩⟨0⊗Nq|U†(γx)]W†(𝜽)]\small y(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\text{Tr}[\mathbf{O}W(\boldsymbol{\theta})U(\gamma x)|0^{\otimes N_{q}}\rangle\langle 0^{\otimes N_{q}}|U^{\dagger}(\gamma x)]W^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta})] (32)

where 𝜽:={θ1,⋯,θd}∈[0,2​π]dassign𝜽subscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝜃𝑑superscript02𝜋𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}:=\{\theta_{1},\cdots,\theta_{d}\}\in[0,2\pi]^{d} and the circuit is defined on Nq=m×1=msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑚1𝑚N_{q}=m\times 1=m qubits.

Now, an encoding unitary can always be written as U​(x)=e−i​γ​x​H𝑈𝑥superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝐻U(x)=e^{-i\gamma xH} for some generator Hamiltonian H𝐻H. Furthermore, one can always write the eigenvalue decomposition of the Hamiltonian as H=V†​Σ​V𝐻superscript𝑉†Σ𝑉H=V^{\dagger}\Sigma V, where ΣΣ\Sigma is the diagonal matrix with eigenvalue entries λ1,⋯,λpsubscript𝜆1⋯subscript𝜆𝑝\lambda_{1},\cdots,\lambda_{p}. The encoding unitary becomes U​(γ​x)=V†​e−i​γ​x​Σ​V𝑈𝛾𝑥superscript𝑉†superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥Σ𝑉U(\gamma x)=V^{\dagger}e^{-i\gamma x\Sigma}V. Let us assume the entries of the matrix V are [V]i​j=vi​jsubscriptdelimited-[]𝑉𝑖𝑗subscript𝑣𝑖𝑗[V]_{ij}=v_{ij}, and the entries of ansatz are [W​(𝜽)]i​j=wi​jsubscriptdelimited-[]𝑊𝜽𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗[W(\boldsymbol{\theta})]_{ij}=w_{ij} where i,j∈[1,2Nq]𝑖𝑗1superscript2subscript𝑁𝑞i,j\in[1,2^{N_{q}}] (since we are defining the circuit of Nqsubscript𝑁𝑞N_{q} qubits).

One can verify that the state takes the form,

[|ψ⟩]j=∑k=1p∑l=1pe−i​γ​x​λk​wj​l​vk​l∗​vk​1​j∈[1,p]subscriptdelimited-[]ket𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑝superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑤𝑗𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑙subscript𝑣𝑘1𝑗1𝑝[\ket{\psi}]_{j}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\sum_{l=1}^{p}e^{-i\gamma x\lambda_{k}}w_{jl}v_{kl}^{*}v_{k1}\hskip 5.69054ptj\in[1,p] (33)

where |ψ⟩ket𝜓\ket{\psi} can be written as a column vector with 2Nqsuperscript2subscript𝑁𝑞2^{N_{q}} entries of which the first p𝑝p entries are non zero with entries given as in the above equation while the rest 2Nq−psuperscript2subscript𝑁𝑞𝑝2^{N_{q}}-p entries are zero.

Similarly, the j𝑗j-th entry for the row vector ⟨ψ|bra𝜓\bra{\psi} is,

[⟨ψ|]j=∑k=1p∑l=1pei​γ​x​λk​wj​l∗​vk​l​vk​1∗​j∈[1,p]subscriptdelimited-[]bra𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑝superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗𝑙subscript𝑣𝑘𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑘1𝑗1𝑝[\bra{\psi}]_{j}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\sum_{l=1}^{p}e^{i\gamma x\lambda_{k}}w_{jl}^{*}v_{kl}v_{k1}^{*}\hskip 5.69054ptj\in[1,p] (34)

Next we want to express y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}),

y​(𝜽)=⟨ψ|​𝐎​|ψ⟩=∑a=1p∑b=1p𝐎a​b​[⟨ψ|]a​[|ψ⟩]b=∑k=1p∑l=1pei​γ​x​(λk−λl)​(∑a=1p∑b=1p𝐎a​b​ca​k∗​cb​l)=∑ω∈ΩAω​ei​γ​x​ω𝑦𝜽bra𝜓𝐎ket𝜓superscriptsubscript𝑎1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑝subscript𝐎𝑎𝑏subscriptdelimited-[]bra𝜓𝑎subscriptdelimited-[]ket𝜓𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑝superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝜆𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑎1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑝subscript𝐎𝑎𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑎𝑘subscript𝑐𝑏𝑙subscript𝜔Ωsubscript𝐴𝜔superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝜔\begin{split}y(\boldsymbol{\theta})&=\bra{\psi}\mathbf{O}\ket{\psi}\\ &=\sum_{a=1}^{p}\sum_{b=1}^{p}\mathbf{O}_{ab}[\bra{\psi}]_{a}[\ket{\psi}]_{b}\\ &=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\sum_{l=1}^{p}e^{i\gamma x(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{l})}\left(\sum_{a=1}^{p}\sum_{b=1}^{p}\mathbf{O}_{ab}c^{*}_{ak}c_{bl}\right)\\ &=\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}A_{\omega}e^{i\gamma x\omega}\end{split} (35)

where in the second step,

ci​j=∑k=1pwi​k​vj​k∗​vj​1subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝑤𝑖𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑗𝑘subscript𝑣𝑗1c_{ij}=\sum_{k=1}^{p}w_{ik}v^{*}_{jk}v_{j1}

Ω={λk−λl,k,l∈[p]}Ωsubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝜆𝑙𝑘𝑙delimited-[]𝑝\Omega=\{\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{l},\hskip 5.69054ptk,l\in[p]\} (36)

and the coefficients

Aω=∑λk−λl=ω∑a,b=1dOa​b​ca​k∗​cb​lsubscript𝐴𝜔subscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝜆𝑙𝜔superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑏1𝑑subscript𝑂𝑎𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑎𝑘subscript𝑐𝑏𝑙A_{\omega}=\sum_{\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{l}=\omega}\sum_{a,b=1}^{d}O_{ab}c^{*}_{ak}c_{bl}

Few things to note here are that 0∈Ω0Ω0\in\Omega, and if ω∈Ω𝜔Ω\omega\in\Omega, then −ω∈Ω𝜔Ω-\omega\in\Omega. Also we have that Aω=A−ω∗subscript𝐴𝜔subscriptsuperscript𝐴𝜔A_{\omega}=A^{*}_{-\omega}, thus y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}) represents a real valued function. Consequently, the size of the spectrum of y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is K,

K=|Ω|−12𝐾Ω12K=\frac{|\Omega|-1}{2} (37)

where in order to compute the size of the spectrum, we exclude the 00 frequency and count ω𝜔\omega and −ω𝜔-\omega as a single frequency. The degree of Eq. 35 is defined as the largest available frequency D=max​(Ω)𝐷maxΩD=\text{max}(\Omega).

Once we have the model output y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}) expressed in the Fourier basis function, the cost function and the gradients can also be expressed in the same basis. Considering the mean squared error as the cost function for input sample (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y), its expansion in the Fourier basis is the following,

Cost=(y−y​(𝜽))2=y2+y​(𝜽)2−2​y​y​(𝜽)=y2+∑ω,ω′∈ΩAω​Aω′​ei​γ​x​(ω+ω′)−∑ω∈Ω2​y​Aω​ei​γ​x​ω=∑ω∈Ω𝒜ω,ω′​ei​γ​x​(ω+ω′)Costsuperscript𝑦𝑦𝜽2superscript𝑦2𝑦superscript𝜽22𝑦𝑦𝜽superscript𝑦2subscript𝜔superscript𝜔′Ωsubscript𝐴𝜔subscript𝐴superscript𝜔′superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝜔superscript𝜔′subscript𝜔Ω2𝑦subscript𝐴𝜔superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝜔subscript𝜔Ωsubscript𝒜𝜔superscript𝜔′superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝜔superscript𝜔′\begin{split}\texttt{Cost}&=\left(y-y(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{2}\\ &=y^{2}+y(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{2}-2yy(\boldsymbol{\theta})\\ &=y^{2}+\sum_{\omega,\omega^{\prime}\in\Omega}A_{\omega}A_{\omega^{\prime}}e^{i\gamma x(\omega+\omega^{\prime})}-\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}2yA_{\omega}e^{i\gamma x\omega}\\ &=\sum_{\omega\in\Omega}\mathcal{A}_{\omega,\omega^{\prime}}e^{i\gamma x(\omega+\omega^{\prime})}\\ \end{split} (38)

where in the last expression the coefficient 𝒜ω,ω′subscript𝒜𝜔superscript𝜔′\mathcal{A}_{\omega,\omega^{\prime}} encapsulates the three separate terms in the third term of the equation. Further, we define the set ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g} such that,

Ωg={ωg=ω+ω′,ω,ω′∈Ω}={(λk−λl+λy−λz,k,l,y,z∈[p]}\begin{split}\Omega_{g}&=\{\omega_{g}=\omega+\omega^{\prime},\hskip 5.69054pt\omega,\omega^{\prime}\in\Omega\}\\ &=\{(\lambda_{k}-\lambda_{l}+\lambda_{y}-\lambda_{z},\hskip 5.69054ptk,l,y,z\in[p]\}\end{split} (39)

Now we can express Eq. 38 as,

Cost=∑ωg∈Ωg𝒜ωg​ei​γ​x​ωgCostsubscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜔𝑔\texttt{Cost}=\sum_{\omega_{g}\in\Omega_{g}}\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}e^{i\gamma x\omega_{g}} (40)

where the coefficient of the different frequency terms ωgsubscript𝜔𝑔\omega_{g} are,

𝒜ωg=∑ω,ω′∈Ωω+ω′=ωg𝒜ω,ω′subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜔superscript𝜔′subscript𝜔𝑔𝜔superscript𝜔′Ωsubscript𝒜𝜔superscript𝜔′\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}=\sum_{\underset{\omega+\omega^{\prime}=\omega_{g}}{\omega,\omega^{\prime}\in\Omega}}\mathcal{A}_{\omega,\omega^{\prime}} (41)

Taking the gradient of the cost expression with respect to the parameters 𝜽∈{θ1,⋯,θd}𝜽subscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝜃𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\{\theta_{1},\cdots,\theta_{d}\} results in,

C1=∂∂θ1​Cost​(y​(𝜽),y)=∑ωg∈Ωg∂𝒜ωg∂θ1​ei​γ​x​ωg⋮Cd=∂∂θd​Cost​(y​(𝜽),y)=∑ωg∈Ωg∂𝒜ωg∂θd​ei​γ​x​ωgsubscript𝐶1subscript𝜃1Cost𝑦𝜽𝑦subscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃1superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜔𝑔⋮subscript𝐶𝑑subscript𝜃𝑑Cost𝑦𝜽𝑦subscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑑superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜔𝑔\begin{split}C_{1}&=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{1}}\texttt{Cost}(y(\boldsymbol{\theta}),y)=\sum_{\omega_{g}\in\Omega_{g}}\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{1}}e^{i\gamma x\omega_{g}}\\ &\hskip 99.58464pt\vdots\\ C_{d}&=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{d}}\texttt{Cost}(y(\boldsymbol{\theta}),y)=\sum_{\omega_{g}\in\Omega_{g}}\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{d}}e^{i\gamma x\omega_{g}}\end{split} (42)

We note that the size of the spectrum for the gradients {C1,⋯,Cd}subscript𝐶1⋯subscript𝐶𝑑\{C_{1},\cdots,C_{d}\} is larger than the size of the spectrum for y​(𝜽)𝑦𝜽y(\boldsymbol{\theta}) because the available frequencies enter as ωg=ω+ω′subscript𝜔𝑔𝜔superscript𝜔′\omega_{g}=\omega+\omega^{\prime}, instead of ω𝜔\omega. We denote the size of the set ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g} by |Ωg|subscriptΩ𝑔|\Omega_{g}|. The total size of the spectrum is (excluding 0 frequency and counting ωgsubscript𝜔𝑔\omega_{g} and −ωgsubscript𝜔𝑔-\omega_{g} as one frequency),

Kg=|Ωg|−12subscript𝐾𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔12K_{g}=\frac{|\Omega_{g}|-1}{2} (43)

Another point to note here is that while the frequency spectrum ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g} decides the number of frequencies that the model gradient function can generate and consequently decides the maximum degree of polynomials that the model gradient can represent, it is also the flexibility of the coefficients 𝒜ωgsubscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}} which plays a key role in final expressivity of the model gradients functions {C1,⋯,Cd}subscript𝐶1⋯subscript𝐶𝑑\{C_{1},\cdots,C_{d}\}. The expressivity of model coefficients is ultimately controlled by the parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} as the Fourier coefficients are not all arbitrary but rather constrained by the degrees of freedom/expressivity of the ansatz. Thus the VQC model with d𝑑d real trainable parameters has the capability of arbitrarily controlling d/2𝑑2d/2 complex coefficients 𝒜ωgsubscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}} out of a total Kgsubscript𝐾𝑔K_{g} coefficients [28].

From the perspective of showing privacy of quantum federated learning as introduced in Sec. VI, we care about the coefficients (especially for high degree frequencies) being non-zero. From the numerical results of [30], it turns out the that the Fourier Tower feature map (as defined in Eq. 15) combined with HEA ends up having non-zero high degree Fourier coefficients (even though they are lower in magnitudes compared to the frequencies that exhibit a high number of redundancies).

V.1.2 Multivariate input analysis

The previous section was the stepping stone to the more relevant case in quantum federated learning where the input 𝐱∈[0,1]n𝐱superscript01𝑛\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n} is loaded into the quantum circuit via the unitary U​(γ​𝐱)𝑈𝛾𝐱U(\mathbf{\gamma x}). The quantum model output is then of the form,

y(𝜽)=Tr[𝐎W(𝜽)U(γ𝐱)|0⊗Nq⟩⟨0⊗Nq|U†(γ𝐱)]W†(𝜽)]\small y(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\text{Tr}[\mathbf{O}W(\boldsymbol{\theta})U(\gamma\mathbf{x})|0^{\otimes N_{q}}\rangle\langle 0^{\otimes N_{q}}|U^{\dagger}(\gamma\mathbf{x})]W^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta})] (44)

where 𝜽:={θ1,⋯,θd}∈[0,2​π]dassign𝜽subscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝜃𝑑superscript02𝜋𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}:=\{\theta_{1},\cdots,\theta_{d}\}\in[0,2\pi]^{d}. Similar to the previous analysis, the encoding unitary can be expressed as,

U​(γ​𝐱)=e−i​γ​(x1​H1+x2​H2+⋯+xn​Hn)𝑈𝛾𝐱superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾subscript𝑥1subscript𝐻1subscript𝑥2subscript𝐻2⋯subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐻𝑛U(\gamma\mathbf{x})=e^{-i\gamma(x_{1}H_{1}+x_{2}H_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}H_{n})} (45)

where in this work, we assume the data encoding unitary to be a product map meaning all the Hamiltonians commute i.e. [Hi,Hj]=0,i,j∈[n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐻𝑖subscript𝐻𝑗0𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛[H_{i},H_{j}]=0,i,j\in[n]. Thus the above unitary can be expressed as,

U​(𝐱)=e−i​γ​x1​H1⊗⋯⊗e−i​γ​xn​Hn𝑈𝐱tensor-productsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝛾subscript𝑥1subscript𝐻1⋯superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐻𝑛U(\mathbf{x})=e^{-i\gamma x_{1}H_{1}}\otimes\cdots\otimes e^{-i\gamma x_{n}H_{n}} (46)

Again, after the eigenvalue decomposition of the Hamiltonians Hi,i∈[n]subscript𝐻𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛H_{i},i\in[n], let the resulting eigenvector matrix be Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} and the eigenvalues be λ1(i),⋯,λp(i)superscriptsubscript𝜆1𝑖⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑖𝑝\lambda_{1}^{(i)},\cdots,\lambda^{(i)}_{p}. Thus the encoding unitary has the simultaneous eigenvalue decomposition of the form,

U​(γ​𝐱)=V†​S​(γ​𝐱)​V𝑈𝛾𝐱superscript𝑉†𝑆𝛾𝐱𝑉U(\gamma\mathbf{x})=V^{\dagger}S(\gamma\mathbf{x})V (47)

where S​(γ​𝐱)=(⨂j=1ne−i​γ​xj​Σj)𝑆𝛾𝐱superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑗1𝑛superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾subscript𝑥𝑗subscriptΣ𝑗S(\gamma\mathbf{x})=\left(\bigotimes_{j=1}^{n}e^{-i\gamma x_{j}\Sigma_{j}}\right), V=V1⊗⋯⊗Vn𝑉tensor-productsubscript𝑉1⋯subscript𝑉𝑛V=V_{1}\otimes\cdots\otimes V_{n}, and ΣjsubscriptΣ𝑗\Sigma_{j} is the diagonal matrix with entries λ1(j),⋯,λ2m(j)superscriptsubscript𝜆1𝑗⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑗superscript2𝑚\lambda_{1}^{(j)},\cdots,\lambda^{(j)}_{2^{m}}, where λk(j)=0,k∈[p+1,2m]formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑗𝑘0𝑘𝑝1superscript2𝑚\lambda^{(j)}_{k}=0,k\in[p+1,2^{m}]. Here U​(𝐱)𝑈𝐱U(\mathbf{x}) and thus V𝑉V are block-diagonal matrices defined on Nq=n​msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑛𝑚N_{q}=nm qubits with Vi,i∈[n]subscript𝑉𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛V_{i},i\in[n] being defined on m𝑚m qubits.

Let us denote 𝝀𝐤:=(λk1(1),⋯,λkn(n))assignsubscript𝝀𝐤superscriptsubscript𝜆subscript𝑘11⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathbf{k}}:=(\lambda_{k_{1}}^{(1)},\cdots,\lambda^{(n)}_{k_{n}}), where the index 𝐤:=k1​⋯​knassign𝐤subscript𝑘1⋯subscript𝑘𝑛\mathbf{k}:=k_{1}\cdots k_{n} with each ki∈[p]subscript𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑝k_{i}\in[p] (given that for each Hamiltonian Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i}, the number of distinct eigenvalues are p𝑝p). Using this bold-index notation, we can write the diagonal elements of S​(γ​𝐱)𝑆𝛾𝐱S(\gamma\mathbf{x}) as,

V.2 VQC in this work

V.2.1 Encoding map to load classical data

As we highlight in Sec. V.1, the ability of a quantum model to learn any unknown function (relationship of input-output) is directly tied to to its Fourier spectrum size and the coefficients corresponding to distinct frequencies. Thus, as mentioned in Sec. IV.1.1, we consider a highly expressive and dense product encoding map which gives rise to an exponential encoding scheme, meaning exponential (in the number of qubits per input dimension) Fourier spectra. Specifically the map we consider is the product map, which we refer to as the Fourier tower map which takes the input 𝐱∈[0,1]n𝐱superscript01𝑛\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n} and realizes the following unitary map on Nq=n​msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑛𝑚N_{q}=nm qubits,

U​(γ​𝐱)=⨂j=1n⨂r=1mRX​(5r−1​γ​xj)𝑈𝛾𝐱superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscripttensor-product𝑟1𝑚subscript𝑅𝑋superscript5𝑟1𝛾subscript𝑥𝑗U(\gamma\mathbf{x})=\bigotimes_{j=1}^{n}\bigotimes_{r=1}^{m}R_{X}\left(5^{r-1}\gamma x_{j}\right) (61)

where the unitary acts on the input state |0⟩⊗Nqsuperscriptket0tensor-productabsentsubscript𝑁𝑞\ket{0}^{\otimes N_{q}} and RX​(5r−1​γ​xj)=exp⁡(−i​5r−1​γ​xj​X/2)subscript𝑅𝑋superscript5𝑟1𝛾subscript𝑥𝑗𝑖superscript5𝑟1𝛾subscript𝑥𝑗𝑋2R_{X}\left(5^{r-1}\gamma x_{j}\right)=\exp\left(-i5^{r-1}\gamma x_{j}X/2\right) is the Pauli X𝑋X rotation operation, and γ=2​π𝛾2𝜋\gamma=2\pi. The reason to choose the prefactor 5r−1superscript5𝑟15^{r-1} to ensure we build a dense Fourier spectra of the cost function gradient output where the dense spectra implies that the difference between the k+1𝑘1k+1-th and k𝑘k-th frequency is always 1 indicating that this gives rise to a compact encoding.

Let us first analyse this in the univariate case where the input x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] and the encoding is defined on m𝑚m qubits i.e. in this case Nq=msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑚N_{q}=m and the encoding map is written as,

U​(γ​x)=e−i​γ​x​X/2⊗e−i​5​γ​x​X/2​⋯⊗e−i​5m−1​γ​x​X/2𝑈𝛾𝑥tensor-producttensor-productsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥𝑋2superscript𝑒𝑖5𝛾𝑥𝑋2⋯superscript𝑒𝑖superscript5𝑚1𝛾𝑥𝑋2U(\gamma x)=e^{-i\gamma xX/2}\otimes e^{-i5\gamma xX/2}\cdots\otimes e^{-i5^{m-1}\gamma xX/2} (62)

The corresponding generator Hamiltonian of the unitary U​(γ​x)𝑈𝛾𝑥U(\gamma x) can be written as,

H=12​(X⊗⋯​𝕀+5​𝕀⊗X⊗⋯​𝕀+⋯​5m−1​𝕀⊗⋯​X)𝐻12tensor-product𝑋⋯𝕀tensor-product5𝕀𝑋⋯𝕀tensor-product⋯superscript5𝑚1𝕀⋯𝑋H=\frac{1}{2}\left(X\otimes\cdots\mathbb{I}+5\mathbb{I}\otimes X\otimes\cdots\mathbb{I}+\cdots 5^{m-1}\mathbb{I}\otimes\cdots X\right) (63)

It can be easily checked that this Hamiltonian has 2msuperscript2𝑚2^{m} eigenvectors denoted by |𝒌~⟩=|k1~​⋯​km~⟩ketbold-~𝒌ket~subscript𝑘1⋯~subscript𝑘𝑚|\boldsymbol{\tilde{k}}\rangle=|\tilde{k_{1}}\cdots\tilde{k_{m}}\rangle, where |kj~⟩=12(|0⟩+(−1)kj|1⟩|\tilde{k_{j}}\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{0}+(-1)^{k_{j}}\ket{1} with kj∈{0,1}subscript𝑘𝑗01k_{j}\in\{0,1\}, and thus 𝒌=k1​⋯​km∈{0,1}m𝒌subscript𝑘1⋯subscript𝑘𝑚superscript01𝑚\boldsymbol{k}=k_{1}\cdots k_{m}\in\{0,1\}^{m}. The corresponding eigenvalue for |𝒌~⟩ketbold-~𝒌|\boldsymbol{\tilde{k}}\rangle is then,

λ𝒌=∑j=1m(−1)kj​5j−12subscript𝜆𝒌superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚superscript1subscript𝑘𝑗superscript5𝑗12\lambda_{\boldsymbol{k}}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}(-1)^{k_{j}}\frac{5^{j-1}}{2} (64)

We are now interested in quantifying the Fourier spectrum of cost function gradient resulting from the model output. For this, we can write equation Eq. 38 as,

Cost=∑ωg∈Ωg𝒜ωg​ei​γ​x​ωg=∑𝒌,𝒍,𝒚,𝒛∈{0,1}m𝒜𝒌,𝒍,𝒚,𝒛​ei​γ​x​(λ𝒌−λ𝒍+λ𝒚−λ𝒛)Costsubscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝒌𝒍𝒚𝒛superscript01𝑚subscript𝒜𝒌𝒍𝒚𝒛superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾𝑥subscript𝜆𝒌subscript𝜆𝒍subscript𝜆𝒚subscript𝜆𝒛\begin{split}\texttt{Cost}&=\sum_{\omega_{g}\in\Omega_{g}}\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}e^{i\gamma x\omega_{g}}\\ &=\sum_{\boldsymbol{k,l,y,z}\in\{0,1\}^{m}}\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{k,l,y,z}}e^{i\gamma x(\lambda_{\boldsymbol{k}}-\lambda_{\boldsymbol{l}}+\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}-\lambda_{\boldsymbol{z}})}\end{split} (65)

Thus the set of accessible frequencies can be written as,

Ωg={ωg=(λ𝒌−λ𝒍)+(λ𝒚−λ𝒛)}subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜆𝒌subscript𝜆𝒍subscript𝜆𝒚subscript𝜆𝒛\Omega_{g}=\{\omega_{g}=(\lambda_{\boldsymbol{k}}-\lambda_{\boldsymbol{l}})+(\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}-\lambda_{\boldsymbol{z}})\} (66)

where 𝒌,𝒍,𝒚,𝒛∈{0,1}m𝒌𝒍𝒚𝒛superscript01𝑚\boldsymbol{k,l,y,z}\in\{0,1\}^{m}. One can also write the set of accessible frequencies as,

Ωg={∑j=1m12​((−1)kj−(−1)lj+(−1)yj−(−1)zj)​5j−1}={cj​5j−1}subscriptΩ𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚12superscript1subscript𝑘𝑗superscript1subscript𝑙𝑗superscript1subscript𝑦𝑗superscript1subscript𝑧𝑗superscript5𝑗1subscript𝑐𝑗superscript5𝑗1\begin{split}\Omega_{g}&=\left\{\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{1}{2}\left((-1)^{k_{j}}-(-1)^{l_{j}}+(-1)^{y_{j}}-(-1)^{z_{j}}\right)5^{j-1}\right\}\\ &=\{c_{j}5^{j-1}\}\end{split} (67)

where kj,lj,yj,zj∈{0,1}subscript𝑘𝑗subscript𝑙𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗01k_{j},l_{j},y_{j},z_{j}\in\{0,1\}. An immediate observation is that cj={−2,−1,0,1,2}subscript𝑐𝑗21012c_{j}=\{-2,-1,0,1,2\}. Thus ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g} would have all possible integer values in the range,

Ωg=[∑j=1m−2⋅5j−1,∑j=1m2⋅5j−1]=[−(5m−1)2,5m−12]subscriptΩ𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚⋅2superscript5𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚⋅2superscript5𝑗1superscript5𝑚12superscript5𝑚12\begin{split}\Omega_{g}&=\left[\sum_{j=1}^{m}-2\cdot 5^{j-1},\sum_{j=1}^{m}2\cdot 5^{j-1}\right]\\ &=\left[\frac{-(5^{m}-1)}{2},\frac{5^{m}-1}{2}\right]\end{split} (68)

This gives us the total size of the set ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g} which is,

|Ωg|=5msubscriptΩ𝑔superscript5𝑚|\Omega_{g}|=5^{m} (69)

Thus the total size of the spectrum in the univariate case is Kg=(|Ωg|−1)/2=(5m−1)/2subscript𝐾𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔12superscript5𝑚12K_{g}=(|\Omega_{g}|-1)/2=(5^{m}-1)/2. We also see the maximum degree of the Fourier component is dF=(5m−1)/2subscript𝑑𝐹superscript5𝑚12d_{F}=(5^{m}-1)/2. This implies that in order to realise the cost function gradient output with a certain fixed degree dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F}, the number of qubits (m𝑚m) needs to be,

m=log5⁡(2​dF+1)𝑚subscript52subscript𝑑𝐹1m=\log_{5}(2d_{F}+1) (70)

This can be easily extended to the multivariate case of 𝐱∈[0,1]n𝐱superscript01𝑛\mathbf{x}\in[0,1]^{n} where the size of the set of accessible frequencies 𝛀𝒈subscript𝛀𝒈\boldsymbol{\Omega_{g}} is,

|𝛀𝒈|=|Ωg|n=5m​nsubscript𝛀𝒈superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑔𝑛superscript5𝑚𝑛|\boldsymbol{\Omega_{g}}|=|\Omega_{g}|^{n}=5^{mn} (71)

This gives us the total size of the spectrum as,

Kg=|𝛀𝒈|−12=5m​n−12subscript𝐾𝑔subscript𝛀𝒈12superscript5𝑚𝑛12K_{g}=\frac{|\boldsymbol{\Omega_{g}}|-1}{2}=\frac{5^{mn}-1}{2} (72)

V.2.2 Overparameterized Ansätze

In addition to privacy, we also desire the FL models to be expressive and trainable. For this precise reason, we consider our trainable ansatz to be overparameterized, which we implement in this case using a number of trainable parameters that scale exponentially in the number of qubits [32, 33]. Overparameterization offers a multitude of benefits in the FL model, namely this makes the quantum model fully expressive by allowing complete control in tuning of parameterized coefficients in Eq. 54. Further, as highlighted in [33], overparameterization substantially improves the trainability of FL model by getting rid of spurious local minima i.e. the local minima are no longer well separated from the global minimum but rather concentrated around the global minimum. This further implies that any trainability issues in retrieving client input during a gradient inversion attack is isolated to the attack side of training and reflects an increased privacy in the model.

For our trainable ansatz, we consider the hardware efficient overparameterized ansatz where the number of trainable parameters scale exponentially with the number of qubits Nq=m​nsubscript𝑁𝑞𝑚𝑛N_{q}=mn, such that,

Num. param≥4NqNum. paramsuperscript4subscript𝑁𝑞\text{Num. param}\geq 4^{N_{q}} (73)

This is a sufficient condition for overparameterisation of the hardware efficient ansatz [33].

VI Privacy in Quantum Federated Learning

Privacy of local data is one of the main highlights of the use of federated learning. As already mentioned in Sec. III.3, typical classical federated learning setups are prone to data leakage of the clients which is a substantial drawback in the existing setups and something that is addressed quite naturally with the use of expressive variational quantum circuits.

As highlighted in Sec. IV.2, privacy is defined in the context where the honest-but-curious server aims to learn the client’s data (unknowns) given a set of gradient updates. Furthermore, we consider privacy in the worst-case data leakage setting for the clients, where the clients execute their quantum circuits perfectly without any noise and compute and share the cost function gradients exactly. We showcase that even in this ideal setting, the server is unable to easily learn the client’s data We note that this is the best case scenario for the server trying the learn the data, as a setting with experimental errors would introduce further noise in the cost function gradients, thus making it harder to learn the data input [64]. Here we showcase the privacy when the cost function chosen by all the clients is the mean-squared error. We note that similar results can be obtained for cross entropy or other chosen cost functions.

VI.1 Information available to the server

Let us start by quantifying the amount of information available to the server from each client,

  • •

    A total of d𝑑d gradient information updates ∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽)subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) of the form of Eq. 30.

  • •

    The batch size B𝐵B employed by clients to perform the training of FL model.

  • •

    Encoding map architecture U𝑈U as highlighted in Figure 3 (the input parameters 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} is unknown but the server knows the quantum gate that is being applied to encode the input).

  • •

    Ansatz architecture W𝑊W as well as the parameters 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} (the server can completely replicate this process).

  • •

    Measurement operator 𝐎𝐎\mathbf{O}.

  • •

    The cost function being applied by the clients (the mean squared error in our case).

VI.2 Privacy: Definition

Consider the setting of Sec. IV.2 where a client performs batch training with batch size B𝐵B. Then for any given batch and any given client, the number of gradient updates shared with the server is d𝑑d (Eq. 30) while the number of unknowns is B⋅(n+|𝒞|)⋅𝐵𝑛𝒞B\cdot(n+\mathcal{|C|}). Thus, for each client, the honest-but-curious server needs to learn (𝐱j,yj)subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗(\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j}), ∀j∈Samp,B=|Samp|formulae-sequencefor-all𝑗Samp𝐵Samp\forall j\in\text{Samp},B=|\text{Samp}|555For simplicity we denote the mini-batch used by the client i∈[l]𝑖delimited-[]𝑙i\in[l] to compute the gradients on as Samp:=[(𝐱j,yj)j∈Samp]assignSampdelimited-[]subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗𝑗Samp\text{Samp}:=[(\mathbf{x}_{j},y_{j})_{j\in\text{Samp}}] with the mini-batch size B=|Samp|𝐵SampB=|\text{Samp}|..

Here, we study the stricter version of privacy of data-leakage to the server by considering the case when the mini-batch size B=1𝐵1B=1 i.e. for each client’s input (𝐱,y)𝐱𝑦(\mathbf{x},y), when d𝑑d gradient information of the form Eq. 28 are shared to server, we study the success probability for the server to output the sample (𝐱′,y′)superscript𝐱′superscript𝑦′(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y^{\prime}) such that,

‖𝐱′−𝐱‖≤ϵ1,|y′−y|≤ϵ2formulae-sequencenormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱subscriptitalic-ϵ1superscript𝑦′𝑦subscriptitalic-ϵ2\|\mathbf{x^{\prime}}-\mathbf{x}\|\leq\epsilon_{1},\hskip 5.69054pt|y^{\prime}-y|\leq\epsilon_{2} (74)

for any desired ϵ1,ϵ2>0subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}>0.

One thing that immediately becomes obvious when choosing the cost function as mean-squared error loss, is that the gradients are of the form Eq. 28,

∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj=−(y−y​(𝜽))​(y​(𝜽+)−y​(𝜽−))Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗𝑦𝑦𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}=-\left(y-y(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)(y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})) (75)

If the output label class y∈𝒞={−1,+1}𝑦𝒞11y\in\mathcal{C}=\{-1,+1\}, then it becomes trivial for the server to know the label y𝑦y from the sign of the gradient. One can also extend this to general multi-class case 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} in terms of recovering the true label value y𝑦y. Thus, here we assume the worst case label leakage scenario where the server can ascertain the value of the labels perfectly. In this case the only hidden part for the server is 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. It turns out that leaking the label information is usually not an issue in federated learning as the client’s data that contains the sensitive information is 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} rather than y𝑦y. Thus we recast the objective of the server in this setting to be able to output,

‖𝐱′−𝐱‖≤ϵnormsuperscript𝐱′𝐱italic-ϵ\|\mathbf{x^{\prime}}-\mathbf{x}\|\leq\epsilon (76)

for some chosen value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

VI.3 Attack strategy for the server

A general attack strategy of the server in order to learn the data input is to solve a system of multivariate polynomial functions in the input space i.e. the polynomials are a function of the input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}. Let us see how we can rewrite the problem of learning the inputs from the gradient information into the problem of solving system of multivariate equations.

Consider the problem setting where each client has a variational quantum circuit as shown in Figure 3. At the t𝑡t-th iteration step, they receive the parameters 𝜽t∈[0,2​π]dsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscript02𝜋𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}\in[0,2\pi]^{d} from the server, where the superscript denotes the iteration step. For simplicity, we refer to 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t} as 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. As highlighted in the previous sections, the clients compute their gradients by considering the mini-batch size B=1𝐵1B=1, i.e., they each pick a training sample (𝐱,y)𝐱𝑦(\mathbf{x},y) from their local dataset and compute the cost function Cost​(𝜽)Cost𝜽\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) with the mean squared error loss function as defined in Eq. 21. From this they can compute the gradients of the cost function according to Eq. 28 which we write as a function of (𝜽,𝐱,y)𝜽𝐱𝑦(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y). We denote these gradients as,

Cj=∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱,y),∀j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑C_{j}=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y),\hskip 5.69054pt\forall j\in[d] (77)

where for simplicity we denote the quantity Ci,jsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑗C_{i,j} in Eq. 30 as Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j}.

It becomes clear that upon sharing the gradient values {C1,⋯,Cd}subscript𝐶1⋯subscript𝐶𝑑\{C_{1},\cdots,C_{d}\} with the server, the task of the server is to learn 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} (here we assume that they can exacly infer y𝑦y from the gradients) such that,

fj​(𝜽,𝐱′,𝐲)=∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,𝐲)−Cj=0,∀j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑗𝜽superscript𝐱′𝐲subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝐲subscript𝐶𝑗0for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑f_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y})=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y})-C_{j}=0,\hskip 5.69054pt\forall j\in[d] (78)

i.e., the model gradient generated by 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} must match the gradients received from the clients.

This is a general system of d𝑑d multivariate polynomial equations fjsubscript𝑓𝑗f_{j} with n𝑛n unknowns 𝐱′=x1′​⋯​xn′superscript𝐱′subscriptsuperscript𝑥′1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑛\mathbf{x}^{\prime}=x^{\prime}_{1}\cdots x^{\prime}_{n}. Here the multivariate polynomial equations emerge upon expanding the derivative of the cost function with respect to the unknown 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} as we see in the following sections. We note that this formalism is completely general and thus also encompasses the classical fully connected Neural network setting we saw in section III.3 where the system of equations generated are linear in the inputs and thus becomes easy to invert in the settings where the number of equations exceed the number of unknowns.

VI.3.1 Generating system of Chebyshev polynomials with quantum circuits

In the case of fully connected classical neural networks, it is seen in Eq. 7 and 8 that the honest-but-curious server’s objective of learning the client’s data reduces to solving the system of equations which are linear in the inputs. The equivalent situation is much harder in the quantum setting as we will now demonstrate by reformulating the gradients generated from the quantum model as high degree Chebyshev polynomials.

As shown in Eq. 42, the individual gradients which the server generates with their attack model in the univariate case x′∈[0,1]superscript𝑥′01x^{\prime}\in[0,1] can be written as a Fourier series with the set of accessible frequencies being ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g},

Cj′=∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,x′,y)=∑ωg∈Ωg∂𝒜ωg∂θj​ei​γ​x′​ωgsubscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝑥′𝑦subscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔subscriptΩ𝑔subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗superscript𝑒𝑖𝛾superscript𝑥′subscript𝜔𝑔C^{\prime}_{j}=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},x^{\prime},y)=\sum_{\omega_{g}\in\Omega_{g}}\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}}e^{i\gamma x^{\prime}\omega_{g}} (79)

where j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d]. Given that the gradients are real values, this enforces the condition on the coefficients of the Fourier expansion to satisfy,

∂𝒜ωg∂θj=∂𝒜−ωg∗∂θjsubscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}^{*}_{-\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}} (80)

Using this fact, the gradient can be written as,

Cj′=∂𝒜0∂θj+∑ωg=1dF2​[Re(∂𝒜ωg∂θj)⁡cos⁡(ωg​γ​x′)−Im(∂𝒜ωg∂θj)⁡sin⁡(ωg​γ​x′)]subscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝑗subscript𝒜0subscript𝜃𝑗superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔1subscript𝑑𝐹2delimited-[]subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝜔𝑔𝛾superscript𝑥′subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝜔𝑔𝛾superscript𝑥′\small C^{\prime}_{j}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{0}}{\partial\theta_{j}}+\sum_{\omega_{g}=1}^{d_{F}}2\left[\real(\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}})\cos{\omega_{g}\gamma x^{\prime}}-\imaginary(\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}})\sin{\omega_{g}\gamma x^{\prime}}\right] (81)

where dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F} is the maximum degree of the cost function frequency set ΩgsubscriptΩ𝑔\Omega_{g}666Note that this is true given our encoding circuit defined in Sec. V.2.1 where the gradient frequencies are integers and dense i.e. separated by 1..

The Chebyshev polynomials are defined as,

The gradients can therefore be written in terms of Chebyshev polynomials as,

Cj′=∂𝒜0∂θj+∑ωg=1dF(2Re(∂𝒜ωg∂θj)Tωg(cos⁡(γ​x′))−2Im(∂𝒜ωg∂θj)Uωg−1(cos⁡(γ​x′))sin⁡(γ​x′))subscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝑗subscript𝒜0subscript𝜃𝑗superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜔𝑔1subscript𝑑𝐹2subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝑇subscript𝜔𝑔𝛾superscript𝑥′2subscript𝒜subscript𝜔𝑔subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝑈subscript𝜔𝑔1𝛾superscript𝑥′𝛾superscript𝑥′\begin{split}C^{\prime}_{j}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{0}}{\partial\theta_{j}}&+\sum_{\omega_{g}=1}^{d_{F}}\Big{(}2\real(\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}})T_{\omega_{g}}(\cos{\gamma x^{\prime}})\\ &-2\imaginary(\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\omega_{g}}}{\partial\theta_{j}})U_{\omega_{g}-1}(\cos{\gamma x^{\prime}})\sin{\gamma x^{\prime}}\Big{)}\end{split} (83)

We will therefore focus on finding the highest degree of the resulting polynomial rather than writing an explicit form.
