∏k=1ncos⁡(ωg​k​xk)=∏k=1nTωg​k​(cos⁡(xk))=∏k=1nTωg​k​(ck)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝜔𝑔𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑇subscript𝜔𝑔𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑇subscript𝜔𝑔𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘\prod_{k=1}^{n}\cos(\omega_{gk}x_{k})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}T_{\omega_{gk}}(\cos{x_{k}})=\prod_{k=1}^{n}T_{\omega_{gk}}(c_{k}) (86)

The maximum value of any ωg​ksubscript𝜔𝑔𝑘\omega_{gk} is dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F} and hence the maximum degree of the multivariate polynomial for n𝑛n data inputs will be dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F}. Hence in the general multivariate case, the system of polynomial equation would have 2​n2𝑛2n unknowns [ck,sk]subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘[c_{k},s_{k}] with a maximum degree of (dF)n=(5m−1)n/2nsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝐹𝑛superscriptsuperscript5𝑚1𝑛superscript2𝑛(d_{F})^{n}=(5^{m}-1)^{n}/2^{n}.

VI.3.2 Analytical solution to Chebyshev polynomials

There are two main challenges to finding a solution to this system of equations that are not present in the classical case previously described. The first is calculation of the coefficient terms ∂𝒜𝝎𝒈∂θjsubscript𝒜subscript𝝎𝒈subscript𝜃𝑗\frac{\partial\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{\omega_{g}}}}{\partial\theta_{j}}, and the second is solving the system of high degree polynomials.

Analytically finding the coefficients would involve symbolically simulating the entire quantum circuit in order the find the gradients of the cost function of the respective circuit model output. This is clearly impractical from a memory and time complexity perspective as the Hilbert space dimension of a quantum state scales exponentially as 2n​msuperscript2𝑛𝑚2^{nm}.

Even if these coefficients are known, then the problem would still involve solving a system of polynomial equations with 2​n2𝑛2n unknowns and max degree (dF)nsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝐹𝑛(d_{F})^{n}. There are techniques in computational algebraic geometry such as Buchberger’s algorithm [34], that can be used to find exact solutions. The worst case complexity scaling of Buchberger’s algorithm has been shown to scale as,

2​(Δ22+Δ)2N−22superscriptsuperscriptΔ22Δsuperscript2𝑁22\Big{(}\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2}+\Delta\Big{)}^{2^{N-2}} (87)

where ΔΔ\Delta is the maximum total degree of any of the polynomials and N𝑁N the number of unknown variables [65]. Hence finding an analytical solution utilizing Buchberger’s algorithm would be upper bounded by a scaling of 𝒪​(5m​n​4n)𝒪superscript5𝑚𝑛superscript4𝑛\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{5}^{mn4^{n}}). The combination of these two issues provides significantly more safety against attacks involving analytical solution finding approach to learn the client’s input.

VI.3.3 Approximate solution to system of equations

Digressing from the pursuit of an exact analytical solution, we can instead explore the feasibility of obtaining approximate numerical solutions for solving the system of Chebyshev polynomial equations. In the context of approximate equation solving, the challenge of determining the coefficients still persists. In the case of solving the system of equations approximately, the task of finding the coefficients still remains. The Nyquist–Shannon sampling theorem offers insights in this regard [35]. It states that for a function with the highest Fourier frequency dFsubscript𝑑𝐹d_{F}, at least 2​dF2subscript𝑑𝐹2d_{F} samples of the function will be required to avoid aliasing effects i.e., the effect resulting in overlapping frequency components resulting in poor coefficient reconstruction. Therefore, in the univariate case, at least 2​dF=5m−12subscript𝑑𝐹superscript5𝑚12d_{F}=5^{m}-1 samples of the cost function gradient (Eq. 85) would be required to obtain the coefficients for that gradient. In the multivariate n𝑛n dimensional case, the number of samples required would be (2​dF)n=(5m−1)nsuperscript2subscript𝑑𝐹𝑛superscriptsuperscript5𝑚1𝑛(2d_{F})^{n}=(5^{m}-1)^{n} given that one would have to sample in n𝑛n dimensions. From here, one needs to obtain the coefficients of the Chebyshev polynomial and subsequently, numerically solve the resulting equations. As discussed previously, this will introduce additional complexity depending on the numerical algorithm utilized.

Since calculating the coefficients, either exactly or approximately, already scales exponentially in m𝑚m, we will explore alternative numerical methods that do not require the calculation of the coefficients, namely machine learning-based gradient inversion attacks. We then argue in further sections that even these attacks require optimization algorithms that will exponentially scale in m𝑚m and therefore expressive quantum models provide inherent privacy in federated learning.

VI.3.4 Gradient inversion machine learning attack

As the previous sections indicate, analytical or even approximate solutions to the system of equations are exponentially hard. We therefore focus our numerical results on utilizing the machine learning-based gradient inversion approach. Given all the information available to the server, their attack strategy to learn the data using the machine learning-based minimization technique is given in Algorithm VI.3.4.

{algorithm}

Gradient inversion machine learning attack

{∂∂θ1​Cost​(𝜽),⋯,∂∂θd​Cost​(𝜽)},W​(𝜽),Usubscript𝜃1Cost𝜽⋯subscript𝜃𝑑Cost𝜽𝑊𝜽𝑈\{\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{1}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\cdots,\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{d}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\},W(\boldsymbol{\theta}),U
Optimize to learn (𝐱,y)𝐱𝑦(\mathbf{x},y).
1. Construct a VQC such that output state is |𝐱′,𝜽⟩=W​(𝜽)​U​(𝐱′)​|0⟩ketsuperscript𝐱′𝜽𝑊𝜽𝑈superscript𝐱′ket0\ket{\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}}=W(\boldsymbol{\theta})U(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\ket{0}.
2. Construct the cost gradient ∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y) using the parameter shift rule or other methods.
3. Repeat the procedure for all j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d].
4. Minimize the loss function of the attack model,
L=∑j=1dLj​(∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y),∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱,y))𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝐿𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦L=\sum_{j=1}^{d}L_{j}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y),\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y)\right)
by optimizing over 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, where L(.)L(.) is a chosen loss function.
5. Learn 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} such that it is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon close to 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} in a distance measure appropriate for the data.

In terms of attempting an approximate solution using gradient descent, we are required to solve a loss function that we chose to be the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} loss function,

L=∑j=1d(∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)−∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱,y))2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦2L=\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y)\right)^{2} (88)

by optimizing over 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} until the gradients match the target gradients. We will refer to the value optimized by the FL model during training as the cost function Cost and refer to the value optimized during the gradient inversion attack as the loss function L𝐿L of the attack model.

In order to solve this with a gradient descent-based attack it is necessary to find the gradient of the loss function with respect to changing the 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} parameters. When calculating the 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} gradients during the FL model training, the parameter shift rule can be used to find the gradients,

∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj=−2​(y−y​(𝜽))​∂y​(𝜽)∂θj=−(y−y​(𝜽))​(y​(𝜽+)−y​(𝜽−))Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗2𝑦𝑦𝜽𝑦𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗𝑦𝑦𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽\begin{split}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}&=-2\left(y-y(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)\frac{\partial y(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}\\ &=-\left(y-y(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)(y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-}))\end{split} (89)

To find the derivatives of these gradients with respect to 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} parameters we can similarly apply the parameter shift rule,

∂∂xk′​∂Cost​(𝜽)∂θj=∂yi​(𝜽)∂xk′​(y​(𝜽+)−y​(𝜽−))+y​(𝜽)​(∂y​(𝜽+)∂xk′−∂y​(𝜽−)∂xk′)=12((y(𝒙′⁣+,𝜽)−y(𝒙′⁣−,𝜽))(y(𝒙′,𝜽+)−y(𝒙′,𝜽−))+y(𝒙′,𝜽)(y(𝒙′⁣+,𝜽+)−y(𝒙′⁣−,𝜽+)−y(𝒙′⁣+,𝜽−)+y(𝒙′⁣−,𝜽−)))subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘Cost𝜽subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘𝑦superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽𝑦𝜽𝑦superscript𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘𝑦superscript𝜽subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘12𝑦superscript𝒙′𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽𝑦superscript𝒙′superscript𝜽\begin{split}&\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial\theta_{j}}=\frac{\partial y_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}(y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-}))\\ &\hskip 73.97716pt+y(\boldsymbol{\theta})(\frac{\partial y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}-\frac{\partial y(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}})\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\Big{(}\big{(}y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime+},\boldsymbol{\theta})-y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime-},\boldsymbol{\theta})\big{)}\big{(}y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})\big{)}\\ &+y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime},\boldsymbol{\theta})\big{(}y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime+},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime-},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{+})-y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime+},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})\\ &+y(\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime-},\boldsymbol{\theta}^{-})\big{)}\Big{)}\end{split} (90)

noting that additional circuit evaluations will be required to compute this quantity as this is a second-order partial derivative. In the partial derivative with respect to θjsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j} and xk′subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘x^{\prime}_{k} the parameter shift variables 𝜽±superscript𝜽plus-or-minus\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\pm} and 𝒙′⁣±superscript𝒙′plus-or-minus\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime\pm} correspond to taking θj→θj±π2→subscript𝜃𝑗plus-or-minussubscript𝜃𝑗𝜋2\theta_{j}\rightarrow\theta_{j}\pm\frac{\pi}{2} and xk′→xk±π2→subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘plus-or-minussubscript𝑥𝑘𝜋2x^{\prime}_{k}\rightarrow x_{k}\pm\frac{\pi}{2} respectively. It is then possible to calculate the gradient of the loss function,

∂L∂xk′=∑j=1d−2(∂∂xk′∂Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)∂θj)(∂∂θjCost(𝜽,𝐱′,y)−∂∂θjCost(𝜽,𝐱,y))𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑2subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦\begin{split}\frac{\partial L}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}=\sum_{j=1}^{d}-2\Big{(}\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x^{\prime}},y)}{\partial\theta_{j}}\Big{)}\Big{(}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y)\\ -\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y)\Big{)}\end{split} (91)

by substituting in the parameter shift values for the first and second order partial derivatives of Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y) along with the known client gradients. We can now utilize this to perform a gradient descent to match the known client gradients while optimizing 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x^{\prime}} in order to attempt to recover the target client’s data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}.

The above machine-learning attack involves the server using the same VQC architecture to compute the gradients with respect to 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} in order to feed it to the above loss function. One can alternatively argue whether it is possible to build a purely classical machine learning attack based on the gradients received from the clients. Such a model would require learning the mapping from the gradient value ∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y) to the input value 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. This would require training data comprising of gradient values alongside their true input values in order to learn the mapping. Generating this training dataset would then require evaluating gradients of quantum circuits many times in order to generate sufficient training data. Furthermore, we expect that the number of training samples required to learn this relationship would likely scale with the highest frequency term so as to not violate the Nyquist-Shannon Theorem [35]. Therefore, there is no practical purely classical machine learning attack, as any classical algorithm will require sampling a quantum circuit potentially exponentially many times in order to initially train the classical model.

VI.3.5 Privacy from machine learning attack

Our key argument for hardness rests on the fact that as m𝑚m increases, the highest frequency per input dimension in the Fourier series increases exponentially dF=5m−12subscript𝑑𝐹superscript5𝑚12d_{F}=\frac{5^{m}-1}{2}. This results in a loss function where the number of local minima points scale exponentially with m𝑚m such that the minima points are uniformly distributed on average across the loss landscape (See Fig. 6 and Fig. 9 respectively). Hence a sufficiently high m𝑚m will generate a loss function where optimizations get stuck close to their initialization point, thus requiring an average number of re-initializations that scales exponentially in m𝑚m to find the global minimum.

We also observe that the average distance between the global minimum and the nearest local maxima r𝑟r decreases exponentially with m𝑚m (see Fig. 10). This means that even an ideal stochastic optimizer with the ability to break out of any local minima would need to limit the distance it jumps each time by an amount proportional to r𝑟r, so as to avoid missing the global minimum, and hence the total number of stochastic jumps would scale exponentially with m𝑚m. Both stochastic and non-stochastic gradient descent methods imply some repeated sampling (via average re-initializations, or average stochastic jumps, required to reach the global minimum) that scales exponentially as the number of qubits per input m𝑚m is increased.

The high-frequency terms make the gradient inversion attack loss landscape hard to train as we vary 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. However, this does not affect the original FL model training since the original model is overparameterized in 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, in contrast to the attack model which is severely underparameterized in 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. Due to the underparamterization of the highly expressive attack model, the local minima are spaced uniformly throughout the loss landscape, making it extremely hard to find the global minimum. Equally spaced local minima also implies that even if the loss function of the gradients is minimized such that L​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)<ϵL𝐿𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿L(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x^{\prime}},y)<\epsilon_{L} (assuming a local minima has loss function value below ϵLsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐿\epsilon_{L}), then while this means it may have found a good fit for the gradients, it could still be the case that |𝐱′−𝐱|\rvert\mathbf{x^{\prime}}-\mathbf{x}\rvert has not converged below a threshold level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and the attack model has failed to recover the client input. This decorrelation between optimizing gradients and recovering user data is shown in Fig. 9.

VI.3.6 Theoretical bound of local minima

With the distinction made between an underparameterized attack model and an overparameterized FL global model, we can focus on exploring bounds on the number of local minima in the attack model, as a measure of how difficult the machine-learning based gradient inversion attack will be. Local minima will occur in the loss function when the gradient of the loss with respect to 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} is equal to zero i.e.,

∂L∂xk′=∑j=1d−2(∂∂xk′∂Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)∂θj)(∂∂θjCost(𝜽,𝐱′,y)−∂∂θjCost(𝜽,𝐱,y))=0𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑2subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦0\begin{split}\frac{\partial L}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}=&\sum_{j=1}^{d}-2\Big{(}\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}}\frac{\partial\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y)}{\partial\theta_{j}}\Big{)}\Big{(}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y)\\ &-\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y)\Big{)}=0\end{split} (92)

We previously identified that the Cost could be expressed in Chebyshev polynomials with 2​n2𝑛2n unknowns and with max degree (dF)n=(5m−1)n/2nsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝐹𝑛superscriptsuperscript5𝑚1𝑛superscript2𝑛(d_{F})^{n}=(5^{m}-1)^{n}/2^{n}. Therefore the corresponding polynomial for ∂L∂xk′𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑘\frac{\partial L}{\partial x^{\prime}_{k}} will have maximal degree 2​(dF)n2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝐹𝑛2(d_{F})^{n}. In the case of finitely many local minima, one can utilize Bézout’s theorem which states that the number of roots of a system of polynomial equations in the non-degenerate case can be bounded by the product of the degree of the polynomials [66],

2n​deg​[∂L∂x1′]​…​deg​[∂L∂xn′]=4n​(5m−12)n2superscript2𝑛degdelimited-[]𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑥′1…degdelimited-[]𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑛superscript4𝑛superscriptsuperscript5𝑚12superscript𝑛22^{n}\texttt{deg}\left[\frac{\partial L}{\partial x^{\prime}_{1}}\right]...\texttt{deg}\left[\frac{\partial L}{\partial x^{\prime}_{n}}\right]=4^{n}\left(\frac{5^{m}-1}{2}\right)^{n^{2}} (93)

Hence the number of local minima is upper bounded by this quantity [67]. It should be noted that this result is for a general system of polynomials. In practice, we find that the average amount of local minima in the loss landscape seems to arise from the highest frequency term in the Fourier series. This seems intuitive considering a model with only a single frequency ω𝜔\omega, for example the function cos⁡(ω​x)𝜔𝑥\cos(\omega x), would contain ω𝜔\omega local minima in the range x∈[0,2​π]𝑥02𝜋x\in[0,2\pi]. Section VII details our numerical results which suggest that on average the gradient inversion attack loss landscape follows a similar pattern.

VI.3.7 Solutions to systems of equations in feature space

In this section, we explore the feasibility of solving the system of equations generated when the gradients of the VQC model is written as a system of equations in the feature space, i.e., as a function of the quantum state |ψ​(𝐱)⟩=U​(γ​𝐱)​|0⟩ket𝜓𝐱𝑈𝛾𝐱ket0\ket{\psi(\mathbf{x})}=U(\gamma\mathbf{x})\ket{0}, instead of directly expressing it as a function of the input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} as we have been analyzing in the previous sections. An immediate observation when directly dealing in the feature space is that, the quantum model output is linear in the ρ​(𝐱)=|ψ​(𝐱)⟩​⟨ψ​(𝐱)|𝜌𝐱ket𝜓𝐱bra𝜓𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x})=\ket{\psi(\mathbf{x})}\bra{\psi(\mathbf{x})} and is expressed as,

y​(𝐱,θ)=Tr​[𝐎​W​(𝜽)​ρ​(𝐱)​W†​(𝜽)]𝑦𝐱𝜃Trdelimited-[]𝐎𝑊𝜽𝜌𝐱superscript𝑊†𝜽y(\mathbf{x},\theta)=\text{Tr}[\mathbf{O}W(\boldsymbol{\theta})\rho(\mathbf{x})W^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta})] (94)

Given that ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}) has no 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} dependency, we can write this out explicitly in matrix elements as

y​(𝐱,𝜽)=∑i,l,k,m𝐎i​l​Wl​k​Wm​i†​ρ​(𝐱)k​m𝑦𝐱𝜽subscript𝑖𝑙𝑘𝑚subscript𝐎𝑖𝑙subscript𝑊𝑙𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑊†𝑚𝑖𝜌subscript𝐱𝑘𝑚y(\mathbf{x},\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{i,l,k,m}\mathbf{O}_{il}W_{lk}W^{\dagger}_{mi}\rho(\mathbf{x})_{km} (95)

We can see from this that, similar to the dense linear classical neural network case where the model output has a linear form with respect to the input, the quantum model output has a linear form in the feature space of ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}), in contrast to the input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} space. The degree of the polynomials of the gradient equations in the feature space will be dependent on the exact cost function used. For example the cost function of the form mean squared error loss will give rise to the gradients of the form,

∂∂θj​Cost=2​(y−y​(𝐱,θ))​∂∂θj​y​(𝐱,θ)=2​(y−∑i,l,k,m𝐎i​l​Wl​k​ρ​(𝐱)k​m​(W†)m​i)∗(∑i′,l′,k′,m′𝐎i′​l′ρ(𝐱)k′​m′∂∂θj(Wl′​k′(W†)m′​i′)))\begin{split}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}&=2(y-y(\mathbf{x},\theta))\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}y(\mathbf{x},\theta)\\ &=2(y-\sum_{i,l,k,m}\mathbf{O}_{il}W_{lk}\rho(\mathbf{x})_{km}(W^{\dagger})_{mi})\\ &*(\sum_{i^{\prime},l^{\prime},k^{\prime},m^{\prime}}\mathbf{O}_{i^{\prime}l^{\prime}}\rho(\mathbf{x})_{k^{\prime}m^{\prime}}\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}(W_{l^{\prime}k^{\prime}}(W^{\dagger})_{m^{\prime}i^{\prime}})))\end{split} (96)

Thus, the resulting gradient expressions are quadratic in the elements of ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}). Hence with sufficiently many gradients (which will be the case if using an overparameterized FL model), one would be able to reconstruct ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}) by solving a system of quadratic equations, which would be easier than solving for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} directly as examined in previous sections. This is a more similar comparison to the classical neural network case.

However, finding the form of the equations to be solved in feature space will in general require explicitly finding the exact form of W​(𝜽)𝑊𝜽W(\boldsymbol{\theta}) in order to perform the appropriate matrix multiplications. This task will scale exponentially in general, in the number of qubits, as was also the case for finding an analytical form of the coefficients in the previous sections.

While solving the system of equations to find ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}) may be easier than for 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, we would then also be faced with the task of retrieving 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} from ρ​(𝐱)𝜌𝐱\rho(\mathbf{x}). The encoding circuit we propose does give a bijective feature map 𝐱→|ψ​(𝐱)⟩→𝐱ket𝜓𝐱\mathbf{x}\rightarrow\ket{\psi(\mathbf{x})}, as long as γ​𝐱𝛾𝐱\gamma\mathbf{x} is between [0,2​π)02𝜋[0,2\pi). However, even given a quantum state |ψ​(𝐱)⟩ket𝜓𝐱\ket{\psi(\mathbf{x})} and knowing the encoding circuit that generates it, it is not possible to find the inverting circuit unless one knows 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} to begin with. To acquire 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} one method would be to calculate the overlap ⟨ψ​(𝐱)|ψ​(𝐱′)⟩=1inner-product𝜓𝐱𝜓superscript𝐱′1\innerproduct{\psi(\mathbf{x})}{\psi(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})}=1 by varying parameters 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}. The problem has been effectively transformed into passing 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} through some feature map, and trying to match it up with the known output of the feature map when 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} is passed through it.

If we wish to maximize the overlap ⟨ψ​(𝐱)|ψ​(𝐱′)⟩inner-product𝜓𝐱𝜓superscript𝐱′\innerproduct{\psi(\mathbf{x})}{\psi(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})} though appropriate cost function minimization, we would again encounter the problem of exponentially many well separated local minima in the loss landscape due to the high expressivity of the encoding map as discussed previously. Due to the simplicity of product feature map we have used to encode the classical data, it is possible in this specific case to write this out in an analytical form (this is not the case in general for a more complicated quantum feature maps). Consider the Fourier tower map for a univariate input x𝑥x described previously using RX​(γ​x)subscript𝑅𝑋𝛾𝑥R_{X}(\gamma x) gates which produces the state |ψ​(x)⟩=U​(γ​x)​|0⟩ket𝜓𝑥𝑈𝛾𝑥ket0\ket{\psi(x)}=U(\gamma x)\ket{0},

(cos⁡(γ​x)​|0⟩+sin⁡(γ​x)​|1⟩)⊗(cos⁡(5​γ​x)​|0⟩+sin⁡(5​γ​x)​|1⟩)⊗⋯⊗cos⁡(5m−1​γ​x)|0⟩+sin⁡(5m−1​γ​x)|1⟩)\begin{split}&(\cos(\gamma x)\ket{0}+\sin(\gamma x)\ket{1})\otimes(\cos(5\gamma x)\ket{0}+\sin(5\gamma x)\ket{1})\\ &\otimes\cdots\otimes\cos(5^{m-1}\gamma x)\ket{0}+\sin(5^{m-1}\gamma x)\ket{1})\end{split} (97)

Clearly each x𝑥x will give a unique |ψ​(x)⟩ket𝜓𝑥\ket{\psi(x)} as can be seen by looking at the first qubit only. To calculate the overlap between two states we want to find ⟨ψ​(x)|ψ​(x′)⟩=⟨0|​U†​(γ​x′)​U​(γ​x)​|0⟩=1inner-product𝜓𝑥𝜓superscript𝑥′bra0superscript𝑈†𝛾superscript𝑥′𝑈𝛾𝑥ket01\innerproduct{\psi(x)}{\psi(x^{\prime})}=\bra{0}U^{\dagger}(\gamma x^{\prime})U(\gamma x)\ket{0}=1. We need to find x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} for which the probability of measuring |0⟩ket0\ket{0} on all qubits in the circuit U†​(γ​x′)​U​(γ​x)​|0⟩superscript𝑈†𝛾superscript𝑥′𝑈𝛾𝑥ket0U^{\dagger}(\gamma x^{\prime})U(\gamma x)\ket{0} is equal to one. If U​(γ​x)𝑈𝛾𝑥U(\gamma x) is known to be the previously introduced Fourier tower map encoding using RXsubscript𝑅𝑋R_{X} gates then we can write the probability of measuring zeros on all qubits as,

|cos⁡(γ​x−γ​x′)cos⁡(5​(γ​x−γ​x′))⋯cos⁡(5m−1​(γ​x−γ​x′))|2\rvert\cos(\gamma x-\gamma x^{\prime})\cos(5(\gamma x-\gamma x^{\prime}))\cdots\cos(5^{m-1}(\gamma x-\gamma x^{\prime}))\rvert^{2} (98)

and we need to find the maximal value of this probability, which will be the case when the function equals 111. This equation in general is a high degree polynomial that must be solved, where the highest degree will be exponential m𝑚m when writing out in Chebyshev form, and hence by previous arguments the difficulty will scale at least exponentially in m𝑚m. Likewise, we can easily see that any attempt at performing any form of gradient descent to find a numerical solution will be swamped with exponentially many local minima due to its periodic nature. These local minima will be uniformly distributed through this cost function and the spacing between these minima will be inversely proportional to 5m−1superscript5𝑚15^{m-1}. It is exactly these properties that manifest also in Sec. VII, although a simple analytical form in the input space is not possible to show explicitly. The system of equations in the feature space are exponentially hard to write down, requiring unitary simulation of the overparameterized variational circuit. If they are written down, they may easier to solve in order to find ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥\rho(x), when compared to trying to find x𝑥x directly. However, even if ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥\rho(x) is found from these equations, then finding the x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} that inverts the state |x⟩ket𝑥\ket{x} will similarly be exponentially hard to solve. Because of several exponentially scaling steps, we will not consider this as a viable attack method and will move on to direct gradient inversion machine learning based attacks, which do not require formulating a system of equations and hence skip this exponentially hard step. However, considering the problem of trying to learn x𝑥x given |x⟩ket𝑥\ket{x} in this example explicitly shows how local minima would appear, and how they would cause machine learning optimization algorithms exponentially long to solve in terms of m𝑚m. This property will reappear numerically in the subsequent machine learning gradient inversion attack.

VII Numerical Results

This section highlights the numerical results solidifying our privacy arguments. We highlight the results involving the machine learning gradient attacks, followed by the analysis on the loss landscape of the attack model.

Taking the scaling factor γ=2​π𝛾2𝜋\gamma=2\pi into account, x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} values are normalized in the range [0,2​π]02𝜋[0,2\pi] for univariate input (and similarly for higher dimensions) in order to cover all unique quantum states when input as rotation angles. Therefore, in these numerical results we report the distance between two values using the closest angular distance between them on a circle defined as,

|x−x′|=min(abs(x−x′),2π−abs(x−x′))\rvert x-x^{\prime}\rvert=\min{(\texttt{abs}(x-x^{\prime}),2\pi-\texttt{abs}(x-x^{\prime}))} (99)

VII.1 Machine learning gradient attack result

Utilizing gradient descent via the ADAM optimization method for the learning rate η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01, we attempted the gradient attack on a univariate model i.e., n=1𝑛1n=1 with m=3𝑚3m=3. The resulting distribution of the distance between the final x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} and client data x𝑥x is shown in Fig. 4. The distribution generated does not show a peak around |x−x′|=0\rvert x-x^{\prime}\rvert=0 and in fact appears uniformly distributed. This implies there is a sufficient amount of local minima distributed such that the probability of convergence effectively depends on the random initialization. Further evidence for this conclusion is provided in Figure 5 which shows there is a linear relationship between error tolerance ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and the probability of a successful attack, where success is defined as achieving |x−x′|<ϵ\rvert x-x^{\prime}\rvert<\epsilon, with a coefficient of determination R2=0.993superscript𝑅20.993R^{2}=0.993. This linear relationship is what would be expected from a model guessing x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} randomly. Hence running ADAM optimization for m=3𝑚3m=3 is no better than guessing at random. Note there may be other stochastic optimization methods that have a higher probability of reaching a solution eventually, however, they would still need to be limited by the width of the valley of the global minimum, which is shown to shrink exponentially as m𝑚m increases in Fig. 10.

VII.2 Analysis of loss landscape

In order to analyze the loss landscape of the gradient attack, we used simulations in Qiskit [68] to calculate the entire loss landscape, for an appropriate sampling granularity, from which the location of all critical points could be identified. This was done by randomly fixing the 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} parameters and client data 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} in the range [0,1]01[0,1], leading to γ​𝐱∈[0,2​π]𝛾𝐱02𝜋\gamma\mathbf{x}\in[0,2\pi], and the client output y∈{−1,1}𝑦11y\in\{-1,1\}. We then calculate the loss of the difference of estimated and target gradients using l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} error. Instead of taking the sum of the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} error of all gradients, in practice, it suffices to find the global minimum of a single gradient,

Lj=(∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱′,y)−∂∂θj​Cost​(𝜽,𝐱,y))2subscript𝐿𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽superscript𝐱′𝑦subscript𝜃𝑗Cost𝜽𝐱𝑦2L_{j}=\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x}^{\prime},y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_{j}}\texttt{Cost}(\boldsymbol{\theta},\mathbf{x},y)\right)^{2} (100)

as the global minimum obtained from matching a single gradient can easily be verified against all other gradients to check if Lj=0,∀j∈[d]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑗0for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑑L_{j}=0,\forall j\in[d]. This significantly reduces the number of circuit evaluations required, especially as we consider circuits that are overparameterized in 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} in this investigation. In these numerical results, the gradient index j𝑗j was chosen randomly from all possible 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} values, excluding the values in the very final layer of the circuit.

Fig. 6 demonstrates that the number of local minima in the loss function for the univariate case scales as,

Nc=0.622​e1.484​msubscript𝑁𝑐0.622superscript𝑒1.484𝑚N_{c}=0.622e^{1.484m} (101)

where Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} is the number of local minima points. Even the two dimensional case exhibits a pattern of local minima scaling as exponential with the number of qubits per encoding m𝑚m. Example visualizations of how the loss landscape changes as m𝑚m is varied can be seen in Fig. 7 for the univariate case n=1𝑛1n=1 and in Fig. 8 for the multivariate case n=2𝑛2n=2.

A large number of local minima does not immediately guarantee that the model is difficult to train. Overparamaterized quantum models have been shown to contain local minima distributed exponentially close to the global minimum [33] which would not pose much challenge to an attack. In the setting of gradient attack however, we are firmly in the underparameterized regime as we have n𝑛n inputs 𝐱′=x1′​⋯​xn′superscript𝐱′subscriptsuperscript𝑥′1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑛\mathbf{x^{\prime}}=x^{\prime}_{1}\cdots x^{\prime}_{n} to vary but Nq=n​msubscript𝑁𝑞𝑛𝑚N_{q}=nm qubits in total. The results shown in Fig. 9 demonstrate the distribution of local minima throughout the gradient attack loss function. While for m=1𝑚1m=1 and m=2𝑚2m=2 the overall distribution is mostly uniform, we can see there is a slightly elevated density of minima close to the global minimum. However, by the time we reach m=3𝑚3m=3 and onwards, the distribution appears uniform.

We see in Fig. 10 that the distance r𝑟r between the global minimum and the next local maxima decreases exponentially as m𝑚m increases, i.e., for n=1𝑛1n=1 the scaling is,

r=3.34​e−1.49​m𝑟3.34superscript𝑒1.49𝑚r=3.34e^{-1.49m} (102)

This is important as it gives an indication of the spacing of random initialization that would be required to guarantee convergence to the global minimum. Additionally, in the case of stochastic gradient descent it also gives an indication of the scale of how far the stochastic term can jump without missing the global minimum. This is the source of privacy against machine learning gradient inversion attacks, as on average both stochastic and non-stochastic gradient descent algorithms will have to sample a total number of points that scales exponentially with m𝑚m. This provides an accessible method of increasing the privacy of the model.

VII.3 Attack model loss landscape analysis as original model is trained

Next, we provide a visual analysis of how the loss landscape of the gradient attack model changes throughout the original training of the FL model, which corresponds to 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} values being updated each epoch as the FL model tries to fit some target function and hence the entire gradient attack loss function is changed at each step. In Fig. 11 we show the gradient attack model loss function alongside the FL model output at various training epochs, as the FL model tries to fit a target function h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x). Note that even though the target function in Fig. 11 is relatively simple, straight lines require a large Fourier series with high degree frequencies to match well, hence the loss landscape maintains high-frequency terms and a gradient attack is hard to perform.

VII.4 Privacy when underlying FL model target function contains only low frequencies

We have shown that the hardness of performing gradient attacks on this model derives from the large frequencies contained in the quantum model. For an arbitrary set of 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} the large frequency terms in the Fourier series that represents the quantum model can lead to a loss landscape that is difficult to train. The results reported so far assume 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} values are chosen randomly, or in the case of Fig. 11 were trained to fit a function that has high degree frequency terms. This leads to the question of whether the privacy of the model would hold if the FL model is learning an underlying distribution that contains only low-frequency components. While in practice real-world data is not likely to exactly match some low-frequency signal, we will consider this case to bring extra insight into the model.

We demonstrate an adversarial example of an underlying distribution that could reduce the privacy of the quantum federated learning model in Fig. 12. When using a relatively low-frequency model m=2𝑚2m=2, the FL model is able to match the target function of y=0.7​cos⁡(x)𝑦0.7𝑥y=0.7\cos{x} almost exactly, and in the process suppresses high-frequency terms. This leads to a simplified gradient attack model loss landscape with reduced privacy. However, we further show in Fig. 13 that a higher frequency model m=4𝑚4m=4 trained on the same function y=0.7​cos⁡(x)𝑦0.7𝑥y=0.7\cos{x} ends up achieving a good fit to the target function, but maintains the high-frequency terms and thus the privacy. This property of quantum models preserving high-frequency terms has been shown to be useful when data is drawn from some signal distribution with an added error, as the high-frequency terms allow overfitting to the data, while still providing good generalization to the signal function overall [69]. In our context the preservation of high-frequency terms during training means that the privacy is maintained while the FL model can still achieve good generalization for low frequency functions.

VIII Conclusion

In this work, we highlight that variational quantum circuits consisting of expressive encoding maps and overparameterized ansätze naturally provide privacy in the context of federated learning. We discern that expressive quantum circuits inherently possess a feature map which transforms classical data into a higher-dimensional Hilbert space resulting in quantum models that encompass high-degree Fourier frequencies. This results in the necessity to solve a system of very high degree Chebyshev polynomials in the input space in order to learn the underlying data. We analyze various techniques of solving such a system of equations, either via trying to solve them analytically, or by using a machine learning-based attack. Our observation is that all these methods lead to an exponential (in the number of qubits) hardness in recovering the underlying client’s input.

We primarily notice that expressive quantum circuits, when underparameterized in terms of optimizable variables, give rise to hard to train loss landscapes in the machine learning-based attack. In the case studied here, the attack model’s underparameterization in the optimizable variable 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} renders it challenging to train, while, conversely, the FL model being overparameterized in its optimizable variable 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} ensures it can be trained without suffering from the issue of spurious local minima.

This inherent dichotomy between overparameterization and underparameterization ensures that while FL models can excel in their designated learning tasks, they simultaneously offer enhanced privacy. Both our theoretical and empirical findings indicate that high-frequency terms contribute to periodic loss functions that are exponentially hard to optimize. This revelation prompts the intriguing question: Could classical federated learning techniques potentially benefit from incorporating highly periodic feature maps during a data preprocessing phase, drawing inspiration from quantum circuit feature maps?

It remains an open question whether classical machine learning methods can effectively navigate this feature space, or if expressive variational quantum circuits are intrinsically better suited for training within these highly periodic feature domains. Future research could also explore the efficacy of quantum encodings which are hard to simulate classically. In this context, our work introduces a novel paradigm in quantum machine learning where a quantum algorithm’s success isn’t solely gauged by its ability to outperform its classical counterpart in terms of model metrics, but also by its potential to offer superior privacy.
